I was probably the only gringo in there and I took that as a good sign, this is where the locals come to get good Mexican. I had the carnitas, some of the best I've ever had and I can't believe I'm saying that. The place isn't much on the outside, but trust me, if you want some great, cheap food and friendly, fast service, go to Las Cazuelas.

reviews.name: John J.
reviews.review: The service is always friendly at this neighborhood favorite. Live music on Friday and Saturday nights is festive but often turned up too loud. Join the fiesta or escape to the back room. Tostada camaron and taquitos Mexicanos are personal favorites. Servings are generous, bar is stocked, Negro Modelo on tap...who could ask for more? Best place in Nashville to catch a soccer game, especially if a central or south American team is playing. Great!

reviews.name: Caitlin D.
reviews.review: I realize that I am in the minority of at least my friends in how I feel about this place. I know a lot of people really like it. I think it is lackluster and the food is bland at best. The prices aren't even cheap, but the quality tastes cheap to me. The only thing halfway decent I've tried here is the shrimp tostada, which was alright, but definitely overpriced for its size. The enchiladas are frankly no good. The chips aren't even fresh tasting, just taste like grease. The salsa is boring as well... sigh, I just don't see what the fuss is about...

reviews.name: Elle A.
reviews.review: Again, I am a huge fan of Nolensville Road restaurants. This is my favorite Mexican restaurant, hands down. Although it is a little out of the way for me, it is always worth the drive. Sometimes (I've seen it sporadically during lunch and dinner) there is even live entertainment! The prices are great and the food, incredible. I always order the Chicken Suiza enchiladas or the Tacos Authenticos with chorizo. It never sets me back more than ten bucks.

reviews.name: Lumnum W.
reviews.review: This place has really become a disappointment over the last few years. The food is never the problem, it stems from poor management/ wait staff. The last visit was it for me, I can't imagine going back. Service is pretty bad- 10 minutes after our drinks were completely empty and we had to stop eating because we were too thirsty, our waitress finally acknowledged we may need something. Then after our meal (not before, during...) our waitress informs us that their credit card machine is broken and we must pay cash and there is an atm at the gas station at the end of the parking lot...she looked at us like it was out fault and that we should do something about this. No sorry for the trouble, nor did she try and swipe our cards- like she was already aware the machine was broken and just decided to tell us as we laid the cards on the table. I have never wanted to dine and dash before but we were pretty close to doing so. We didn't have enough cash so we wrote a check and told her we weren't going to an atm. WTF? Have you ever heard of something so dumb? If you must eat here, get it to go or carry cash to cover the meal. Otherwise find something better, Nolensville Rd has plenty to offer.

reviews.name: Mark M.
reviews.review: It's not industrial US Mexican like other places.  It's not necessarily 'authentico' Mexican either.  It's more like Mexican pub grub.  Not ate up with families with kids like some other suburban Mexican places are.  It's a diverse crowd of all types of people.  My favorite (although I can't have it often...for obvious reasons) is the Alhambre with steak.  Picture a stainless steel plate hot and sizzling with steak, onions and peppers and BACON covered with cheese.  Some tortillas, some lettuce and guac on the side, but the main event is spicy steak, with bacon, covered with cheese.   Like I said, I can't get it very often, but when I get it, it rocks.  My dining partner swears that their Carnitas are the best in town.  Chips are good, salsa is nice and spicy, green salsa upon request is good.  Cheap, fun, quick, and with big screen tv's showing soccer.  Apparently, there are bands on the weekend which are supposed to be a lot of fun.

reviews.name: cliff m.
reviews.review: Haven't been here for a couple years. It was excellent then and excellent now. I had an old college buddy visit who has gone vegan. I immediately thought of this place: baseline vegetarian with the ability to turn almost anything into vegan fare. Since they're vegetarian to start with you can trust that when they give you a vegan dish it truly IS vegan. That's very important for those who want vegan meals. Further, it was nice that the server was careful to reinforce what was vegan and what wasn't so my friend wouldn't mistakenly eat something in our frenzy of consumption... Everything was so good it really was a feeding frenzy. I must continue to support a place that can offer a strictly vegetarian / vegan menu that will make you feel that you don't need a shred of meat to enjoy amazing flavor. Every dish we ordered was fantastic... Perfectly seasoned... Full on delicious. I LOVE this place and highly recommend it to anyone. But especially to my vegan and vegetarian friends as an amazing option where you don't have to sacrifice flavor or substance to meet your dietary goals. Did I mention I LOVE THIS PLACE!?

reviews.name: Asher B.
reviews.review: Coming from Bombay, I've eaten more south Indian food than most of you'll reading this review would have.First, Nashville needs more places like this. I miss hogging on medhu vadas!!I ate the buffet on a Sunday morning. The place was packed as most reviews state and unfortunately they weren't taking any orders so I only had the buffet to contain myself to. They do have pani puri on the buffet which is neat. I enjoyed their medhu vadas with some chutney and Sambhar. My friend had the idlis and she seemed to enjoy em too.I'd go back should I crave south Indian food.

reviews.name: Penelope B.
reviews.review: Woodlands has a great all-vegetarian South Indian lunch buffet.  Vegan and gluten-free items are marked and there is quite a solid variety.  The food is well-spiced, so get some raita or a little extra rice if you're vegan.  Everything I had was delicious, and the added safety of knowing what was or was not safe made it a much more relaxing experience.  They do also have some Chinese-style dishes including fried rice.  Watch out for these if you have issues with soy.  They are marked gluten-free so probably it's tamari but I do not know for sure.  You will get a dosa with your meal.  The dosa is gluten-free.  Mine showed up at my table while I was at the buffet so I didn't get to ask questions about it and vegans may want to be careful.  The big downsides here are the parking, which can be very awkward if you don't get one of the spots just outside the front door, and the price.

reviews.name: Prashant S.
reviews.review: Best Indian restaurant in town. Can never go wrong with Gobi Manchurian dry with Garlic Naan. They now offer free valet parking due to construction nearby. May have to wait few minutes for valet but totally worth it!

reviews.name: Alisha L.
reviews.review: Voted Best of Nashville for a reason! I'm vegan so this is a place I like to visit frequently. I'm not someone who could tell you how authentic something is, but I can tell you that everything I've had the pleasure of stuffing my face here with was delicious! Bring a friend and enjoy the giant silverware on the walls as decoration. The buffet is pretty great too!Try the naan!

reviews.name: Denny K.
reviews.review: Djarleeing...Oh how I've patiently, albeit anxiously, awaited this epicurean encounter. And, as Etta sang so appropriately..."at last my love has come along." We meet, we eat, we sway in thyme to the concert of dining sounds: the clink of cups, the sibilant slip of silverware accompanied by the wafting aromas of spice and herbs dispensing their charm. We begin our wanton wandering through the extensive menu with Assorted Appetizers: Vada and Veggie Pakoras, a tiny bit dry, but seasoned sensationally with the four accompanying dipping sauces, each highlighting a special flavor: spicy tomato, coconut, tamarind, and cilantro. The savory sauces also complimented the Idly and Bonda. But nothing was needed to heighten the flavors of the wonderfully stuffed Samosa.My dining guests and I shared a bevy of Dosas, Curries, Naan, and Sambar...a great mix of textures, flavors, heats, and savoriness.My greatest joy was the curiously named Gobi Manchurian Gravy. (Sometimes things just don't translate, save for the fantastic flavors.) This Indian-Chinese dish features Cauliflower "curds" (often misnamed as florets) which are blanched then lightly battered with seasoned cornflour and quickly deep fried. The texture is similar to stir-fried trumpet mushrooms...sensory-sensational. They are served in a sauce, reminiscent of pureé made with sun-dried tomatoes--very hearty, very bold, very aggressive--lightly kissed with garlic, green onion, soy and cayenne. I figuratively flipped over this dish (narrowly missing tables as I fell...not). And, as a parting note, Djarleeing ... I may have missed you at dinner, but this carnivore did not miss the meat at this delightful, completely Vegetarian, restaurant.This engaging culinary expedition to the foods of South Asia was worth every Rupee. It's da "Bomb"-bay says this Yelper ("Burrpee" in India burpp.com)

reviews.name: Jamie L.
reviews.review: It's been years since I have eaten here. Indian is my absolute favorite cuisine and I still talk about how much I loved this place. I wasn't sure I'd be a fan as it's vegetarian and I usually get lamb in anything I order. I didn't miss the meat at all! They use wonderful spices and cooked everything to perfection. We received great service also. I cannot wait for another road trip that takes me through Nashville so I can come back.

reviews.name: Hattie J.
reviews.review: Great place! Love going on a Sunday for brunch. All vegetarian selection...and delicious! Their pal baaji is fantastic...and I always leave room for some of their gulab jamun!

reviews.name: Alisha W.
reviews.review: Great authentic Indian food.  I love how it is BYOB and that the portions areBig enough to take home leftovers.   The menu is very long so look at it at home before going because they like you to order promptly!! The parking is a nightmare so make sure to get there early so that you can find a spot or navigate around back to park.  The previous time I dined at woodlands we had amazing service and a great meal.   This time the service was a bit more sporadic and our meal came out wrong.   They forgot to add the potato in our potato and onion dosa,  so after we told them they fixed it and the dosa looked like it just went through a military zone to get back to us.  It was disappoint the presentation of it but it was still very good.

reviews.name: Kristina L.
reviews.review: 3.5 but I will round up to 4 stars.While my knowledge of what is good versus bad Indian cuisine is nil, I can speak to what it is that tastes good to me.  That being said, I really like Woodlands.  I must also admit that I am a huge carnivore and had that looming in my mind when I first stepped foot in this place.Fortunately, I had a co-worker along that was better versed than I who could walk me through some of the dishes.  While I cannot recall everything that is available during the lunch buffet, I can tell you that I was delighted with the sauces that were dressing the different main courses.  I am a huge fan of their chutneys and the basmati rice.  Rice truly is something that, if not done properly, could ruin all the other dishes it plays host to.While I've not been any other time but for the lunch buffet, I can say that I am always glad I came.  I need to remember this place for Fridays during Lent.On the downsides, parking is an absolute bear here.  You almost need to stalk someone to snag a spot!  Just sayin....

reviews.name: Loralyn D.
reviews.review: I've been to this place a few times and have had a good meal every time I've been.  If you're looking for a quick lunch, they have a lunch buffet with a ton of choices and is not too expensive.  Their dinner menu is also great and comes out really quickly.  I'd also recommend this place for vegetarians and vegans.

reviews.name: Bryan C.
reviews.review: Seriously some of the best Indian food I've ever had.  Friendly servers, and clean environment.  Wish I could eat here every day.

reviews.name: Andre' M.
reviews.review: This fully vegetarian buffet was great.The parking was very difficult as we had to drive all around the back of the building but could never find a spot. We finally parked on the street of a nearby neighborhood.  Not a bad walk and good after the huge feast.

reviews.name: Jamee C.
reviews.review: I work close to here and visited the lunch buffet and enjoyed it very much. I did not miss the absence of meat, the food was tasty (in standards of a buffet) and I can see myself going back here for the buffet.

reviews.name: James M.
reviews.review: This is my favorite Indian place in Nashville. I went here again for lunch today on a whim with my fiancee and we loved it just as much as always. It's always so tasty that it more than makes up for it being vegetarian.I would write glowing reviews of the individual dishes i had but I can't remember any of the names so I'd be reduced to saying the orange one and the green one were phenomenal. Instead, I'll write what I do remember. They give you these little crepes filled with goodness when you sit down for your lunch buffet. They are fresh and warm and so tasty! My favorites that I can remember were the Coconut Curry which has cauliflower and other veggies in a spicy, deep, creamy Indian curry and the Palak Paneer (spinach with cheese dish). Pros:Such amazingly flavorful and bright food. It's always a good day when you can have Woodlands.Cons:Decorations could use some updating but that's being picky. If you must have goat or chicken, this is not your place (as the name implies).Overall:If I had to recommend one Indian place to a friend, this is it!

reviews.name: S. L.
reviews.review: Outstanding - just great, wholesome food and helpful staff

reviews.name: Liz R.
reviews.review: My (very non-vegetarian) friend and I checked out this place for lunch and both indulged in the buffet. Best decision I've made in Nashville. Every dish was perfectly seasoned and there was so much variety. It was impossible for me to pick a favorite. My friend was even more vocal about how delicious he thought it was and how he didn't feel meat deprived. His last words to me when I dropped him off at the airport: You have to go to that Indian place again before you leave Nashville. Oh, I certainly will.

reviews.name: Alexandra H.
reviews.review: If you've never had Indian cuisine before, the lunch buffet is a great opportunity to try a lot of different dishes.  I also recommend the mango milkshake to help cool your palate from some of their spicy offerings.Sometimes parking can be tricky, so try to get there early.  Generally the turnover is quick, so a spot may open up every 15 minutes or so.

reviews.name: Richard H.
reviews.review: I love Woodlands! I moved into the building above it so that I could eat there more often. Their vegetable curry is delicious.

reviews.name: Alisha S.
reviews.review: The masala dosas are the best you can get from anywhere around. If I could, they would be the only thing I'd eat.

reviews.name: Jim V.
reviews.review: Ok...I don't like Indian food at all! However, I was pressured to keep trying this place out. I was not disappointed! Everything was very tasty, maybe not the highest quality, but very tasty. The best part about this place was definitely the BYOB option. Which even keeps your "out to eat budget," in line. Our group had around 7 dishes, and the bill totaled 75 bucks. Where else can you go out to eat in Nashville, drink, eat, and socialize for around 75 bucks? No where. That is why this establishment has received the best of Nashville awards. Two negatives, service and cleanliness of the restaurant. Other than that, I strongly recommend this eatery

reviews.name: PC N.
reviews.review: Went today for Sunday buffet, great food and service. I'm not a vegetarian at all but really enjoyed the flavor of the food and actually got full. Not enough parking spots, it's at the bottom of a hi rise condominium. Up there with Taj as the best Indian spot in town.

reviews.name: Steve B.
reviews.review: God I love this place and I go every time I'm in Nashville.  Meat is found completely unnecessary here and you'll forget all about that fact when the food arrives.  Go for the lunch buffet it's worth it but the regular menu is fantastic too!

reviews.name: Melody P.
reviews.review: Everything about it was average. Food, atmosphere, employees. Food lacked spice. Not one item on lunch buffet made me sweat! : ) kick up the heat!

reviews.name: Candice C.
reviews.review: I wish I lived closer! This lunch buffet is great!! It's all vegetarian with a lot of vegan options as well. It's so busy that the dishes are always hot and fresh. They have a really good variety. One of my fave Indian places!

reviews.name: Johnny T.
reviews.review: I was guilty of judging a book by its cover. As my friends pulled up to the swingingly seventies building that houses Woodlands, I was looking for the escape cord. 'No way,' I thought. Had I left things there, I would have missed out on some very tasty grub. There's a reason why the dining room was packed for an early-ish dinner on a Thursday evening. People looking for affordable vegetarain Indian fare know where to come. Here. They come here. The dining room won't win any HGTV contests. It's very very red. The color red usually agitates me so I willed myself to go into a Zen-like state. This was helped by the chai tea I ordered. This was so so much better than anything a green mermaid could dream up. Despite the tea being hot and me ordering the drink during summer, I had to stop myself from gulping it all down at once. Mmm, cardamom... Chillaxed from my beverage, it was time to order. One of the great things about ordering Indian food in a group is the opportunity to try a lot of things at once. Despite this being (I think) a south Indian restaurant, I didn't opt for a dosa. I'm pretty particular when it comes to dosa and had to test the waters before jumping in. I'm fairly certain that I'll be ordering dosa upon my next visit. The food was really tasty. With copious amounts of steamed basmati rice and garlic naan at the ready, we jumped in to the ordering pool and came out happier people. My entry in to the food goodness was the coconut curry. I know it doesn't sound adventurous but who needs adventure when there's cauliflower, peppers, onions, tomatoes, and potatoes to be had? The curry milk broth wasn't too soupy and the consistency allowed the vegetables to shine, rather than be drowned in the mix. The baingan bartha and malai kofta were big hits as well. Don't be deceived by the metal bowls in which the food comes. Between 3 adults and one child, we couldn't finish four entrees (with naan and rice and raita). I know! I was surprised, too. Our server seemed mildly humored by our fear of a spice planet and he was very friendly and helpful during our meal. I left Woodlands understanding why it has such a fiercely loyal following. I plan on joining. Look for it on the western tip of West End.

reviews.name: Sheena T.
reviews.review: Man, this place really doesn't get enough credit and I am just as guilty as most in not giving them the business they deserve. If I'm craving Indian food, I typically want something of the chicken variety. But after a recent re-visit I have been reminded of how great this restaurant is! The food is very reasonable and cheaper than most Indian restaurants. The menu is very extensive, and I can also speak to the buffet being great as well. The only thing that has made my experience slightly lackluster is that the service can be somewhat rushed. We had a large group and they were slightly impatient with us, but I can't exactly fault them for it as we were somewhat disorganized. Really enjoy the food here, and I need to make more of an effort to support them!NOTE: They are very accommodating with dietary restrictions (vegetarian, vegan, etc) and are BYOB with no corkage fees!

reviews.name: Charles C.
reviews.review: One of the best vegetarian restaurants in Nashville...especially if you want to avoid the crowded hipster type places in East Nashville.  The food and service here are always spot on.  We have taken non-vegetarian friends here on several occasions and they always love it.  We are very lucky to have Woodlands in such a convenient location.

reviews.name: T W.
reviews.review: I eat here once a week usually as it's close to my work, priced right for a buffet, and unique in it's offerings.  I love many of their dishes, but not all.  Because it's vegan, I'd prefer to have a chicken or lamb dish, but still find myself very satisfied and almost always have exceptional service.  Can get busy during the lunch rush, and not a location for much ambiance, but still a regular stop for me with a very satisfying and unique lunch offering.

reviews.name: Kristen W.
reviews.review: Very delicious, authentic Indian cuisine! I was so impressed by how much variety in food there was and how DELICIOUS the food was! I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for a good meal.

reviews.name: Laura B.
reviews.review: This place is the jam. I love so many menu items and the location is really convenient. The mango lassi isn't jaw dropping but I just think the place deserves 5 stars every day I've ever been for every meal I've ever had there was truly delicious.

reviews.name: Kitcat S.
reviews.review: My husband and I just absolutely love this place. An Indian coworker introduced us to it. I was at first hesitant of the vegetarian proposition but I have to say that after going there 15 or so times, not once have I missed having meat in a meal at Woodlands. We lived in NY for years and this rivals the best of what I have seen there. The prices are perfect. Not too many desserts we love but we used it as an excuse to extend our trips to Jeni's on 12th or Sweet Cece's by Vandy. Our favorite dishes are the Paneer Rava Masala Dosa and the Palak Paneer.

reviews.name: Vijay R.
reviews.review: Pretty average Indian food. Definitely enjoyed the variety and ambiance. But better than I expected in Nashville! I might be a little critical because I showed up at the end of the lunch buffet (1:30 pm), which closes at 2:30. And I'm Indian.

reviews.name: Jammie M.
reviews.review: A must visit!  Some of the best Indian food I've had in several years and I eat Indian food at least every 1-2 months.

reviews.name: Alvin P.
reviews.review: This is probably one of the best Indian Restaurants I've been to, and by far the best in Nashville.   I'm pretty much a vegetarian (although the occasional hot dog seems to slip through my security zone every now and then) so this is right up my ally.   The staff seems friendly, and I've never really had to wait much whenever I've been there, albeit I haven't gotten the chance to go there for their lunch buffets.  The place seems clean as well.  The waiting area is a bit small, but since I haven't had to wait there much, doesn't seem to be much of a problem.  The food is amazingly good if you like Indian food, and the varying degrees of to which they can adjust spice comes in really handy if you have a sensitive tongue.  The Dosa here is excellent and so are the Aloo Paratha.  They have plenty of choices as well, and almost all of them seem good.  I've tried various dosas, appetizers (samosa, pakora, vada, etc), curries, parathas, naan,  poori, and bhatura's, and they all seem to be really good.  I don't think I've ever really been disappointed going here.   The only possible negative that I can think of is the parking.  It's basically on the side of an apartment building, right besides 440, so parking can get tough especially if it's the weekend.  There is parking in the back, but I believe some of it is reserved for the apartment building, so that can get tricky.  This is one of those places that people will keep returning because the prices aren't exorbitant (nor are they particularly cheap) but the food is amazing.   I recommend this place to pretty much anyone that likes vegetarian Indian food.  Pretty much when my gf or parents come to visit Nashville, they always make atleast one trip here. And last but not least, controversial advice from my parents:  Judge an ethnic restaurant by how many people of that ethnicity visit it and/or are seen when you visit.  I'd say this passes that benchmark, although it's skewed because I visit it often, :D

reviews.name: Blake R.
reviews.review: Been coming here for years... never had a bad dish! I regularly order malai kofta,  bhatura, masala dosa. I never leave hungry or disappointed.  The service is pretty darn good and the food comes out pretty fast. Even though it is a vegetarian restaurant,  I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this place to anyone

reviews.name: J A.
reviews.review: After spending a few weeks in Malaysia, it's the only place in Nashville that comes close to the authentic southern-style Indian food of vegetarian curries with other eclectic dishes to boot. We eat at Woodlands about once a month and are always excited for the Manchurian Corn.We had Woodlands cater a graduation party for 35 people and they were more than helpful in suggesting dishes and helping stay within our budget. It all came steaming fresh and excellent--as Woodlands consistently is. I can't wait to plow through the leftovers!

reviews.name: Marci R.
reviews.review: Food is really good. Service is good as well. Worth a visit!!

reviews.name: Dennis L.
reviews.review: Great Indian food. Caters to vegetarians and nonvegetarians like. Service was good. Food was delicious. Buffet style.

reviews.name: Om B.
reviews.review: 4 words: great food, packed house. Came here to stop by for lunch after a long day of travel. As a southern-Asian, I can say it's worth stepping by this tucked away eatery in the 'burbs. Mixed crowd of all ages, between toddlers and seniors (which gives you an idea of the ambience). Try the palak paneer and the apps, also the complementary mini-masala dosas. Service par to subpar due to volume. But they tried. Nevertheless, can't go wrong.

reviews.name: Ashley T.
reviews.review: I have been wanting to try woodlands out for a while now, but am usually never out near west end. It is located in what looks like a hotel. Hard to find unless you know that and eyeball your gps like crazy. We had to turn around the first time. Anyway we went for dinner with a couple out of town friends last night. My husband and I ordered the vegetable pakora appetizer to start. It was really so good. I liked both the tamarind sauce and the mint chutney sauces that came with the appetizer too. Hubs ordered the vegetable jalfrezi and added paneer, and I ordered the mysore masala dosa. He said he loved his as much, maybe more than our favorite Indian place back home. I had never tried dosa before and I'll admit it was a toss up between that and the palak paneer. I almost always order spinach at Indian restaurants because I love it so much, but I decided to try something new. The dosa itself was fine. Nothing mind blowing, but okay. The actual filling was so good but there was SO little of it! My friend ordered a dosa as well and hers came wrapped up like 3 fat burritos with a ton of filling. Mine was laid flat on the plate with a tiny roll of filling underneath one corner. I left satisfied, but I was the only person at the table without leftovers. Next time I will definitely order something else. I do like that the menu denotes everything that is vegan and/or gluten free.

reviews.name: Don G.
reviews.review: Pretty impressed. It was a busy Sunday night. The place was pretty full. Service was fast and professional, never felt that I was lacking for anything while also not feeling like someone was hovering over me. Food was excellent and very well prepared. Had some Mushroom Masala and Masala Dosa and it was all excellent. My dining companion wasn't into spicy things so everything was mild. She felt it to be just right, I could barely detect anything that I would call "spicy." Just goes to show that everyone has a different opinion on that. I'll say I felt that the dinner prices were slightly high but they're really in line with other Indian restaurants that I've visited.

reviews.name: Sandy T.
reviews.review: As far as vegetarian restaurants in Nashville, Woodlands gets 5 stars from me. I love Indian food. I do not know the names of most of the specialty dishes, but I can certainly point at the pictures on the menu and tell you which ones (all of them) are good.  There is just something about their simple, staple and humble ingredients that makes me find comfort and familiarity in each dish. It's rice, legumes, and vegetables...highly spiced to make the most out of them - that's it. Oh, before I forget, Woodlands is closed on Mondays! (Just didn't want you to drive all the way there and be disappointed).Their buffets are excellent. Lunch is served 11 am - 2 pm...$8.99. The buffets consist of a variety of several different kinds of soups, salads, curries, rice, desserts, and breads.  A great appetizer: Samosas are delicious especially with the variety of chutneys it's served with (tamarind and mint). My favorite dish is the Rava Masala Dosa. It's a crepe filled with spicy potatoes and vegetables. It's crispy on the edges yet soft and tasty on the inside! The Vegetable biriyani and Ghanna baturo (big fluffy bread served with chickpeas masala) are also delish! If you order a la carte,  I recommend to order several different dishes then share with the other guests on your table because the portions are quite generous....but if you want to be greedy and not share, then I hope you really like your entree and don't choke! Customer service is superb.  The staff is very friendly! Very attentive, respectful, helpful attendants.I say go spice up your buds!

reviews.name: Cee D.
reviews.review: Excellent Indian food, and really, ethnic food of a quality that is not found in many U.S. cities. I've always found the service impeccable, and have never had a bad item. I wish I lived closer and frequented Woodlands more when I was just down the street in college. Don't make the same mistake I made!

reviews.name: Josh M.
reviews.review: This is hands down one of the best vegetarian restaurants in town, not to mention the best Indian food. All of the wonderful smells, textures, spices and colors will make you not even miss the meat. Mango Lassi is incredible and is a must. The location and parking trouble is worth a visit to the lunch buffet. The service is also great.

reviews.name: Gabrielle D.
reviews.review: I love southern indian food, it's a cuisine that is everything and more I could ever hope for as a vegetarian.  It give me comfort and satisfaction like no other!That being said, I've tried a number of southern indian restaurants and this is one of the best.  I've eaten here late at night before they closed and during dinner rushes, and other then waiting a few extra minutes, I've never had issues with service.Their food is flavorful and delicious and the staff can easily tell me what is safe to eat being gluten free.  We often order more then we need so we can take it home and eat the leftovers the next day.My favorite go to meals here are Uthappa, like an indian pizza! Sourdough flavor and gluten free.  Their Aloo Gobi is great along with their Vegetable Jalfrezi, Vegetable Koorma and Mushroom Masala.Even non vegetarians love this place, so give it a shot even though its a vegetarian restaurant.  They are able to bring a lot of flavor!  You won't even miss the meat!

reviews.name: Prasanna K.
reviews.review: Excellent ambiance and great South Indian food..ravi onion dosa is the best so far that I ever had in USA ..I come from New Jersey and have been to several Indian restaurants in NJ and NY and woodlands in Nashville is one of the best

reviews.name: Huzefa M.
reviews.review: Food is ok, but the servers are RUDE and terrible. We were from out of town and didnt know what time they closed the buffett. 10 minutes into the meal, they asked us to take 'all that we can' since they were closing the buffet. I mentioned that when we came in to be seated, they should have verbally mentioned to us that they were closing the buffet. The server started arguing that I should have 'read' the signs outside the restaurant before coming in. Really rude waiter, thought no end of himself and was raising his voice at us at the restaurant. I am not sure why management even hires such losers. It spoilt our entire experience at the restaurant. As for the buffet, the right thing to tell the customer is that although the buffet is closed, we can get portions of whatever you sampled and liked al a carte. That is called customer service. You dont tell a customer that no more food is available to you, specially when a customer has paid for a buffet.We are certainly not going back and we are going to recommend to our network not to go there.

reviews.name: Christa P.
reviews.review: We went with our family and vegan couple. My husband and I are both meat-eaters, but did have a lot of different options on the menu to enjoy. My husband ordered the brijahani (rice) and was disappointed. I ordered the tikka masala, although I asked for extremely spicy and it came out mild. We also did the pakora and somosas as appetizers which were not prepared well. Overall we were disappointed with the flavor and preparation of the food- and we both ended up getting sick.

reviews.name: David C.
reviews.review: Love the food here. Really impressed by the quality and the price. They are very busy sometimes, but sure is worth the wait. Only once when I went the server was quick to drop the bill and ask that we pay and leave because they are on a wait. I have served tables for the majority of my working life and I have never said this to a table (and I'm a New Yorker!) we literally just finished eating and we're finishing our drinks. This would make sense if we sat there for a while but this was not the case. Other than the rude server I love woodlands.

reviews.name: Brian N.
reviews.review: I've been eating here two or three times a month for years, but this, inexplicably, is my first review.  This place is fantastic.  They have a buffet at lunch, and a full menu at dinner.  I'm a vegetarian, and it's such a treat to be able to eat anything they offer without having to modify it.  The service is always exceptional and incredibly friendly without being overbearing.  I admit that the food on the buffet could be a little spicier, but that's the price you pay for eating buffet food: it has to appeal to the greatest number of people, so it's not as spiced as it could be.  It's still well worth going, and it's very cheap for the quality of food and service.  Is it the best Indian food I've had?  Not by a long shot.  But it's still a great place to go, and I've always been glad when I've gone.

reviews.name: Eli C.
reviews.review: Excellent buffet. Super consistent, nice staff and always busy. Also the apartment building it's housed in reminds me of Miami Vice so you feel pretty cool walking in and out.

reviews.name: Peter V.
reviews.review: BEST BUFFET IN TOWN!!!This is the best place to go for your indian fix. I don't have too much to say about Woodlands other than It is consistently delicious, the service is prompt, it is affordable, you can bring your own alcohol, and I have never had to wait for a table even when it is full. Could you ask for anything better?This is my #1 weekend splurge plan. I love to eat myself silly at the buffet then go home and take a nap to help digest. Days off like that are rare but when they happen, they make life worth living.

reviews.name: Justin B.
reviews.review: Everything is great about this place.Personal favorites:Malai Kofta - best Indian dish I've ever had.  Some sort of cashew sauce with fried lentil dough balls swimming in it.Chana batura for an appetizer.  Huge fried, puffy fried bread that shrinks to a manageable size when you stab it with a fork.  Comes with spicy chickpeas in a curry sauce.Palak paneer. - some Indian places make this a goopy mess, but this doesn't have that pureed look.  A go to.Mango lassi.  Sweet, mango yogurt drink.

reviews.name: Crystal B.
reviews.review: A hidden gem. I've been coming here for many years and have never had a bad experience. The food is fresh, flavorful, and always exciting. Tonight we ordered the appetizer sampler, dosas, baingan bharta, dal mahkani, and a curry along with naan. Everything was was delicious and we left stuffed. Service was great and everyone was very attentive. A big plus is that you can BYOB.

reviews.name: Julie S.
reviews.review: Good food, diverse menu with many vegan options! Unfortunately the unwelcoming, unfriendly service overshadowed our whole evening out. Good food though!

reviews.name: Renu K.
reviews.review: On the way back home from trip Looking at the name woodlands in yelp told my hubby for sure we gonna hv lunch here. Thn quickly fed the address in the map found.  1. It was little close to Exit. Was hard to find the exact spot bks thr was one huge building and this is in some continent hotel building and opposite to some gas station.2. Food was Awesome! 3. Service initially thought it was rude bks I think it's manager or some main In charger of the restaurant said it's 2.30 and closing time. We felt little annoyed for a sec thn he said u can pick the buffet in one shot. We said anyways we wanna the menu still he said again u hv to order in one shot. We agreed though we felt little rude but later on the same person and the other waiters amazed us by their service till the end of chk out they treated us so well felt homely. 4. South Indian thali was too good. Sambar, Rasam was awesome and in that fruit dessert tasted yum and you can choose tea or mango lassi. We had tea and it tasted goo d wth nice cardamom aroma. 5. Veg pulao wth raita and a papad had a average taste. 6. Then I ordered Bombay baaji and that tasted yum. I dint know they will give along wth white rice later on my hubby said mostly all the side dish they serve wth white rice. So keep in mind before ordering for side dish or double chk wth them bks I was too full after eating pulao and I need to get box to pack them. 7. Then we ordered their special dosa and idly for to go came home hungry and had that for dinner. Omg! It was a bliss the dosa tasted so yum wth potato masala, sambar and chutney( thought the chutney might hv got spoilt since we had it after 6 hrs but to my surprise it tasted awesome) But Idly was dry and dint taste that good. Bill was totally some around 80$ yeah newyork price :( :' but taste was too good. So I will strongly recommend.

reviews.name: Ben M.
reviews.review: Great service, nice atmosphere, phenomenal food. Well deserving of their 4.5 star average.

reviews.name: Arshbir G.
reviews.review: Good dosas!

reviews.name: Liz H.
reviews.review: Delicious Southern Indian food and the best vegetarian place in town in my opinion. The lunch buffet was bomb and the place has a very relaxed vibe (so rare for a West End restaurant). Even if you are not vege (which I am not) you aren't missing out on a thing. Go now before this gem is discovered by the throngs of new Nashvillians!

reviews.name: Micheal P.
reviews.review: Every time I eat here, I think, "Why did it take me so long to return?"Woodlands is killing it. I mean, most of it. Not animals. But in every other way, killing it.

reviews.name: Bridgette C.
reviews.review: I've only ever had the lunch buffet here, but its very good.  I've already written about my favorite Indian place in town, but Woodlands is a great lunch spot.  A huge vegetarian buffet for under $10?  Yes, take me to my table and allow me to embarass myself at the buffet.It can get crowded in here at lunch but its not a long wait.  The food is very good, but again, keep in mind that this is VEGETARIAN people, so don't ask where the meat is.  The service isn't exemplary, but its a buffet, so you really don't need someone hovering over you all the time.  I'd be interested to see what it's like at dinnertime here.They have salad options, mild curries, some spicy ones as well, and some dessert offerings, and they bring you a veggie-stuffed crepe of some sort (sorry, don't know what its called, aforementioned server kind of dropped it off and ran) that's a great compliment to your meal.This is a good stop for a mostly healthy lunch with lots of options for everyone.  And the price is more than reasonable.  I'd recommend it even if you're slightly rushed.

reviews.name: Ritu S.
reviews.review: Food is just Wow! Enjoyed every bite. My kid liked it too. Awesome food. Want to visit again and again.

reviews.name: Mohankrishna S.
reviews.review: No salt in any item. Iddly is bland. Coconut chutney is bland. Sambar is tasteless. Baby corn manchuria is ok but again no salt. 2 ravva  dosas has the same ingredients and no salt. This is the second time and definitely my last time.

reviews.name: Ashley K.
reviews.review: Best Indian Food in town! Great for take out, very friendly staff and quick service. I love their Bhindi Masala! Fav go - to dish.

reviews.name: Anna J.
reviews.review: I'm giving this place average rating BC i cannot survive on veggies alone.  So this review is totally BIASED.  Read only if you are a meat eater!The buffet here was good, but after I finished eating, i still felt the need to eat some chicken, or beef, or... and within a few hours, i was hungry. So for you meat eaters out there, try Bombay palace down the street... just as good Indian buffet but with chicken chicken chicken!Ok vegetarians, don't judge me.

reviews.name: Tanmay S.
reviews.review: I am not going to beat around the bush !People who rated this indian restaurant any more than 1 star really doesn't know what Indian food is and must have not been outside Nashville EVER !   Chilly Paneer - had more green peppers chilly than paneer. I ll upload the pic of it. Trust me!Noodles : stale stale. What a shame. I thought they served me leftover from their buffetSchezwan dosa - 1 star belong to this.Onion Utthapa - i am sorry but utthapa without butter is meaningless for even health freaks. This was bland with just onions sprinkled over but no flavor.

reviews.name: G. Mary A.
reviews.review: Delicious! Great service. We were in a rush and they were really accommodating even though they were packed.

reviews.name: Hernan G.
reviews.review: Great food, fast service.  The Palak Paneer is especially delicious.

reviews.name: Samantha O.
reviews.review: Absolutely love this place. I ordered to-go and unfortunately was stuck in traffic so I ended up being about 20mins later than I expected but I called to let them know about the delay. They said it was no problem and my food was hot and ready when I arrived! Will definitely be eating here again.

reviews.name: Tom L.
reviews.review: Came here today at noon for the lunch buffet after one previous dinner visit, and I must say I know what all the hype is about. For ten bucks you can pile your plate with what has to be some of the most amazing South Indian food in America, and I say this having been to dozens of South Indian restaurants in multiple major cities. This is the kind of food that is so amazing it makes you want to keep eating even though you're stuffed, just for the culinary sensation it provides your palate. As if the multitude of vegetarian curries, rice dishes and chutneys on the buffet weren't enough, you are also provided with top-notch masala dosas brought to your table. I'll be dreaming about this buffet tomorrow. Definitely as good as it gets.

reviews.name: Sejal M.
reviews.review: This is a great restaurant! If you are vegetarian in particular you should check it out!

reviews.name: Craig W.
reviews.review: Great vegetarian Indian cuisine in the center of it all. Woodlands offers some of the best in Nashville, not to mention one of two that serves Dosa. I highly the Mysore Masala Dosa if you are wanting a great combination of spices and a little kick of hotness. The food is always great, the service is always good, and it makes for a fun night out with friends. My only negative remark is the parking. The parking lot is shared with the apartments community above the restaurant. Don't let this deter you from visiting Woodlands, because it is well worth the wait.

reviews.name: Leslie G.
reviews.review: OK, so positive reviews of Woodlands from meat-eaters inevitably follow a simple format:1) State that you're "not all that into" vegetarian cuisine, or that you were "never that into it," or that you're just generally way into meat and the day really isn't complete unless you've messily devoured an entire suckling pig or something. Bonus points if you broadcast the fact that your horrible vegetarian friends dragged you here.2) Describe in lavish detail the specific dishes that convinced you that Woodlands is, in fact, a wonderful place to dine, and rhapsodize about how your meal was in no way diminished by not having fragments of selected animal carcasses lurking within it.3) Complete your conversion narrative! Lord, lord almighty, you have seen the light!So yeah, I'm not a vegetarian either, so I guess I'll quit making fun of you now. The reason that Woodlands is so awesome is twofold: first, they have a huge and intimidating menu with everything you could possibly want on it. The descriptions are cryptic, many of them are strongly similar, and you'll find yourself wondering about what will actually come out of the kitchen. I ordered puri there once because I was in the mood for something lighter, and they served me an enormous puffy bread somewhat larger than a football that I cautiously prodded with my knife for fear that it might emit some sort of hazardous spume (spoiler alert: it did not). Second, everything is fantastically prepared, reasonably priced, and very very tasty. The curries with almonds and/or cashews are my favorite--nutty and spicy.OK, so I lied: the reasons are actually threefold--it's also BYOB. Thus, your dinner can be as fancy as you want it to be. Feel like a night on the town? Bust out that bottle of Dom. Want to slum it with your hipster friends? Bring a suitcase of PBR (unless, of course, PBR has been supplanted as the crappy beer du jour, in which case bring along your Genesee or Natty Ice or Night Train or whatever swill the youngsters are drinking these days).Finally, some superlatives: this is most definitely the best Indian food in Nashville. I hesitate to describe it as one of the best Indian restaurants in the South / the nation because I haven't dined at all of them yet, though I'm working on this.

reviews.name: Munni P.
reviews.review: I was on the way, and googled for this Restaurant. I went for a buffet they let us in and stated pressurizing we are going to close in 10 min and need to finish quickly, one or the other bugger used to come and stand, These guys are arrogant. I ordered to go veg Pulav for my kid, later I realized these buggers packed left over biriyani of buffet.

reviews.name: Ryan P.
reviews.review: Hard to find; look for the 3401 West End building; Woodlands is in the ground floor.  Also, get here before noon to beat the lunch buffet rush. Additional parking around the back.The chow is good.  I'm not sure it lives up to the hype, but it was very tasty and the buffet had a nice variety of things to try.  The tomato soup they had that day was excellent, and naan they bring to your table is stuffed with some sort of manna I didn't recognize (but didn't care since it tasted so good).  I'll definitely go back when I need an Indian fix.

reviews.name: Rachel W.
reviews.review: This vegetarian spot is one of my favorite Indian restaurants in Nashville even though I am a card-carrying meat eater.I dream about their soup, and the crepe wrapped potato appetizer they bring out when you order a dinner entree, and they have a great lunch buffet. They don't serve alcohol, but it is BYOB, which made for one of the best birthday parties I've been to in Nashville- we basically brought in a group of 20, ordered everything on the menu, split a few bottles of wine and had a ball. The only confusing thing is where to park. There are a few spaces in front. The lot behind the building looks like it's all reserved for the residents of the apartment complex above it, but you can park in any uncovered spot for the restaurant.

reviews.name: Anna V.
reviews.review: Wonderful! Buffet has all of the best items. I could eat here everyday.Really great staff for an Indian restaurant.

reviews.name: Sharmeela S.
reviews.review: Best Indian restaurant in Nashville.  The mort authentic.  The best variety and quality.  I love the Channa Bhatura I'm going for dinner.  For lunch I always get the buffet.  The Golab jamun is delicious.  The food is the perfect spice level. I'm not vegetarian but this is still where I go when im craving moms cooking in Nashville.  Its located at the first floor of a tall apartment building with limited parking on the front but a huge lot at the back if the building.

reviews.name: Holly H.
reviews.review: Awesome South Indian place, tucked under a stack of condos next to the interstate on West End.  Their lunch buffet is clearly labeled for vegan and/or gluten free folks, which saves a lot of trouble and misunderstanding when trying to figure out what you can eat. If you're ordering dinner, the menu is massive and reasonably priced, and they're totally willing and able to answer your questions. They stay on top of your water too, so it's nice not having to track someone down every time you need a refill. They can get really busy during weekend buffets, but I've never had to wait longer than 10 minutes or so. Parking can be a pain when they're packed, as the back parking lot is for the housing above the restaurant, but worst case scenario, you have to walk a little bit farther. I've eaten here for years and have never had a bad experience.

reviews.name: K S.
reviews.review: I have been to this place twice now and I think although the intention is to serve indian food at this restuarant, I think some cost saving measures were also taken into account while cooking food. In addition, they have tried seating me in the entrance / exit when they do have room in the back.The choices were moderate, but I think the food contains more than moderate amount of cooking soda which makes you eat less and stomach bloat.  My recent visit made me feel like, I ate less than normal of what I eat at home.  And on my 4hr drive back home, my stomach felt bloated and I burped all the way.The taste on all items from each visit in my view is not the same.

reviews.name: John S.
reviews.review: Great food, especially if you like vegetarian options. Of the three West End indian places (Woodlands, Bombay, and Sitar), this one offers the best and tastiest vegetarian options. Being a meat-lover myself, I went for lunch buffet with a few of my meat-lover friends and we were all very satisfied with the food. Definitely a solid choice.

reviews.name: Todd G.
reviews.review: I do love Woodlands... as a vegetarian, it is always nice to be able to eat a menu safely without worrying or wondering. I eat here at least once a week. They have a nice variety on the buffet and it changes daily. Some days are incredible but all days are good.... and I like that. They get you in quickly, even when busy. If you are a vegetarian it is one of Nashville's best vegetarian offerings...and is also one of the best indian restaurants in town.         As with most indian restaurants the buffet is the best option. Dinner can get pricey but the lunch buffets are quite a deal indeed. Mnnnn I think I'll eat there tomorrow.

reviews.name: Sarah M.
reviews.review: Go here. If you don't know what to order, try this:-Vegetable soup-Bhel puri-Cheese uthappa-Garlic naan   -Palak paneer

reviews.name: Steve T.
reviews.review: Came back for dinner when in Nashville on business. Great meal. Loved the dosa with onions and potatoes. Eggplant entree excellent also.

reviews.name: Sam L.
reviews.review: Woodlands is one of the more authentic Indian restaurants in Nashville. It is South Indian food, with good dosas. Parking can be challenging at night but you can park across the street. Very good vegetarian food.

reviews.name: Cher Y.
reviews.review: WOW.    A restaurant that makes vegetarian dishes super tasty on a consistent basis?  Great taste, great value for the price and great variety in terms of the menu.I have tried their buffet as well, and it is pretty good for the price --they do a great job of making sure the buffet items are tasty and fresh. Friendly service, nice cozy atmosphere and always a pleasant experience dining here with friends. Parking can be a headache sometimes (due to it being located in an apartment complex) and being busy, but def worth it in terms of the food!A hidden Nashville gem in terms of fantastic Southern Indian cuisine that can please both vegetarians and meatlovers alike.

reviews.name: Janette C.
reviews.review: My favourite Indian food place in Nashville.....the lunch buffet is amazing and delicious and they often have different items on the buffet to try as well!   It is quite good and often there is little to no wait.   They get you seated and get you checked out and on your way again.  Try it :)

reviews.name: Tony W.
reviews.review: Great service, very authentic feel ... great price too.

reviews.name: Essence L.
reviews.review: Love it. Eat here. Doesn't matter that it's vegetarian. Very flavorful. It's busy during lunch and parking is an absolute pain. Still worth it. Did I already say eat here? Yes I did, you can see where I typed it the first time.

reviews.name: Mala H.
reviews.review: I always warn my friends when I bring them here that you are coming for the food and not the service, and once you taste it you just won't care how mediocre the service is. I would say once you come more regular they get to know you and the service improves somewhat. Give it a chance this is a busy place and the employees are really hardworking and good people.Another thing I tell my friends is to remember this is South Indian cuisine, please do not come in here and start ordering like you are at Bombay Palace or probably every other typical indian restaurant you have been too. There's more to it than just the curries and naan. Be prepared to use your hands.You are coming here for the Dosa. If you know nothing about Dosa, order the Masala Dosa. Most non-indian people don't really know how to eat it. It comes out looking like a huge crepe with potato in the center. What you do is tear off a piece of the dosa, pick up a small amount of potato, then using your hand dip this in the sambar (that's the soup looking stuff it came with) then before taking a bite dip it again in the coconut chutney, then eat it. If you don't foodgasm from the flavor sensation in your mouth, you somehow did it wrong. I may start giving lessons.Another must is the gobi manchurian dry, which is an appetizer. I don't know what is possibly indian about this dish, but its better than crack and you must order it. It's a Large portion, more than enough for 2 people.I also recommend the samosa chaat. Very tasty and generous portion.If you are still unsure and intimidated, go for the lunch buffet. You will experience so much of the menu and you won't have to think. The thali is also a good option at dinner time that will give you variety. Everything is good. The best curry is the eggplant.I brought some vegans here and the owner customized all our items to suit the dietary restriction and they all still tasted amazing.Good luck!

reviews.name: Zeb M.
reviews.review: After hearing so much about Woodlands and wanting to go for a while, I finally made it today - just in time for the lunch buffet!If you ask me what my favorite food there was, I couldn't tell you because I cannot remember/spell/correctly pronounce the dishes. But oh so delicious. If you know someone who says "What in the world do vegetarians eat? Salads?" you should take them here.

reviews.name: Kaylaa C.
reviews.review: decent food, but not great. Left feeling irritable.

reviews.name: Nooresha F.
reviews.review: Decent food but terrible service... One of the servers actually had such terrible attitude that I had to literally tell him to stop talking to me that way... Personally, I've tasted better Indian buffets at other places..

reviews.name: Kat F.
reviews.review: Fabulous lunch buffet! Nice variety of curries, rice, salad, soups, sauces, and desserts, and they also bring a dosa to each person at the table. For about ten dollars, you can have a delicious and very filling meal. (I think it is also cheaper on weekdays than on weekends.)Also, my meat-loving boyfriend even enjoys their food, despite the lack of meat. Everything is flavorful and satisfying!

reviews.name: Andrea R.
reviews.review: Delicious food and unlike the other reviews we experienced very friendly and helpful service. I think our water got refilled seven times during the coure of our meal. I had the vegetable pakoras and the tempura veggies. Yum! Everything was delicious but he garlic naan was what sold me. So delicious and cooked perfectly. We will definitely be returning! Refreshing to find an all-vegetarian and vegan friendly restaurant in Nashville.

reviews.name: Annie P.
reviews.review: I love this place. Typically, I do not go to Indian restaurants because I think no one can beat my mother's cooking but this place sure comes close. I am not from Nashville, but I do regularly visit my friend. Every time I'm in town, I head over to Woodlands. Their food is as authenthic as it gets and you can tell because the place is crawlings with Indians (me included). It is hard to find a decent restaurant that makes good masala dosa but theirs is amazing! They also come in cool flavors like one is stuffed with cheese (very unusual compared to the traditional one). I love their mango lassis, their curries, their naan, there's nothing I don't love about the place. The service is impeccable as well. The parking lot is a little small but doable. I love this place and I'm so sad that it's so far away from home!

reviews.name: Mitch S.
reviews.review: Guilt free , vegetatrian paradise !  No compromising here. If  you like/love indian food and you are  vegetarian or vegan you'll have a blast exploring the myriad of optionsIMO Indian food is so complex that even those who usually eat meat won't miss a thing.How did such a place wind up in the mid south I'll never know,  but I'm glad it did!

reviews.name: Michelle T.
reviews.review: So happy to find some good Indian food!  We ordered the thali dinners, and they were way too much for us to finish, so we took the leftovers home.  I think one of those thali meals could've fed two of us!  This is a southern Indian vegetarian restaurant.  They've also got some of the Indian-Chinese food, like Gobi Manchurian.I ordered the Woodland Special Thali for $18, and my dining companion ordered the South Indian Thali for $16, and he added a mango lassi.1. Garlic naan, $3.  This was a good naan.  Some places give you garlic naan with burned garlic on it, or (at the other end of the spectrum) too-raw garlic.  This one was balanced, not burned, nor raw.  Served with a small container of raita.2. Rasam (thali).  Delicious spicy tomato soup!  Very good.3. Sambar (thali).  Very good!  Honestly, and this is kind of sad, I couldn't quite tell the difference from the rasam.  I really liked both, though!4. Samosa (thali).  Very good!  Two samosas with green sauce (cilantro/mint?) and a sweet red sauce (tamarind?).  The sauces were excellent.  The samosa pastry was nice and flaky, slightly oily, but not overly so.5. Chapati (thali).  Very good, but not what I was expecting.  Usually when I get chapati, it's a brown (whole wheat) bread, and a bit thicker than this one. This one was a yellow color, and thin like a crepe.6. Vegetable pulav/biryani (thali).  Very good!  Some saffron, some turmeric, some rehydrated dried fruits (raisins?), some nuts.  Nicely balanced.7. Dal (thali).  Very good!8. Curried green beans (thali).  Good!  Slightly salty, but good.9. Curried chickpeas (thali).  Very good!10. Papad (thali).  Umm.  I was so full I didn't try this until the next day, and so it had become soggy.  Seemed ok, although it didn't look like the papadams I usually get in Indian places.  Was more of a uniform brown color rather than the more yellowish speckled with black that I'm used to.  I think the taste was a bit blander than what I'm used to also.  Not bad or anything, but different.11. Indian tea (masala chai) (thali).  Good!  Didn't seem to have much (any?) sugar in it, which is fine.  I'd rather add sugar to taste than get a super-sweet tea, although I didn't bother adding sugar to this one.  It was pretty good already, and I was too busy eating!12. Carrot dessert (carrot halwa?) (thali).  Pretty good, a bit too sweet for my taste, but nice overall.13. Mango lassi, $3.50 ($1 if added to thali).  Excellent!  Not one of those disgusting glow-in-the-dark orange artificially-colored/flavored mango lassis.`14. Masala dosa (thali).  Pretty good!  Not too oily.Menu prices on their website are slightly out of date as of today (3/14/2012).Overall: Solid Indian food, all vegetarian, they also advertise that they have vegan options.  Very veg*n-friendly!  Note they're closed Mondays!  I may have spent $18 on my thali, but it was so much food, that I had more than enough for lunch the next day, so the value is pretty good.Service: Good, friendly, prompt.Ambience: Nice Indian decor.Location: Inside hotel, but visible from the street if you look carefully.  (Sorry, forgot the name of the hotel).Parking: Some parking in the lot in the front, also in the back..

reviews.name: Marcia M.
reviews.review: You would think that I being a vegan who loves ethnic foods that Woodlands would be a frequent stop for me, right?Yet for some reason, today's visit was only my second in the entire 4 years that I have been a Nashville resident.Very odd especially since they offer a fairly tasty buffet full of vegetarian and vegan Indian goodness. I enjoyed my plate full of food today but would love to also try out entrees from the menu too.Nothing wowed me but I can't really complain offer as the bill for 2 diners to partake in the buffet was around $18.

reviews.name: RShan S.
reviews.review: The hotel hygiene is horrible and the food standards are very poor! I am a travelling IT consultant who travels to Nashville. I have been to this place (Woodlands) couple of times since this is the only Vegetarian Indian restaurant in the Nashville area and I like Dosa and Idli which is also VERY AVERAGE!  I have heard lot of friends complain stomach pain after eating dinner here but I experienced myself on 03/26. I regret eating dinner here on 03/26 since I was served spoilt food twice in a row with a new plate:Details:  I ordered roti's with Chenna - Saag and it was served with fungus that had a bad smell. I requested replacement and it again came back in a new plate. I called the manager and complained. The manager accepted stating that the hotel had left food out on Sunday and they are closed on Monday. So, by mistake they cooked bad food. In general, even otherwise the hygiene is very poor. All night I had to be in the bathroom and I am still recovering from food poison. PLEASE DO NOT GO TO THIS RESTAURANT UNLESS YOU WANT TO RISK YOUR HEALTH AND STAY SICK FOR A LONG TIME AND EVEN GET DANGEROUS STOMACHE DISEASE!!

reviews.name: Jason M.
reviews.review: I'm giving them 4 stars because they only have gulab jamuns sometimes... I get very disappointed when I go for lunch and they don't have the jamuns. The dosas are fantastic... you get a hot fresh one with the lunch buffet...  The korma is my favorite... the cauliflower fritters are good too. I love the south indian white rice with nuts and everything they put in it. Everything is here is great... Just need to have the jamuns on the buffet everyday guys... Sometimes I come here even when I'm not craving indian just to get some gulab jamuns! Seriously!

reviews.name: Dee B.
reviews.review: Decent buffet but nothing spectacular. I went at about 11am when the resturant first opens and the bar has fresh food out. No crowds at this time. The service was good, they were very tentative to our needs. I appreciate that aspect of my experience.

reviews.name: Rahel K.
reviews.review: Alright, alright.  I am not an Indian food connoisseur by any means.   I am a meat eater.  I also love wine.  So why did I give a dry Indian vegetarian restaurant 5 starts?  Because I love this restaurant.  Although the menu is intimidating, it can still be interpreted with relatively no surprises when your meal comes.  You can also bring your own bottle which makes your bill very reasonable.  The atmosphere is very nice even though it is located in a condo building.  Give this restaurant a try even if you are meat-eating, wine-drinking southerner like me!

reviews.name: Blair S.
reviews.review: Woodlands is a rare ethnic food gem in Nashville. I was a regular while in grad school a few years ago. The place has really caught on since then, expanding, renovating, and best of all, filling up with customers. Despite being more busy, it's still a hidden treasure.Yes, they have a buffet (never tried it). Yes, they have typical Indian dishes. But their specialties are Southern Indian dishes, especially dosa. I love the onion rava masala dosa. I also enjoy the South Indian thali and Woodland special thali.The service is helpful, explains menu items helpfully, and delivers food quickly. Prices are very reasonable too.

reviews.name: Gabe D.
reviews.review: This place has outstanding Indian food. Everything on the menu is delicious. I especially like their dosas, which are a typical southern Indian dish. The lunch buffet is very tasty and a great value!  I have eaten here about ten times, and the service and food are always top notch. It's great for the whole family (even toddlers), or for a date night. The atmosphere is calm and casual.

reviews.name: Paul K.
reviews.review: Based on another yelper's suggestion (Peter K) I came back here... I had originally planned on going back a few weeks ago, but New York and life got in the way... so it did not happen until the 9th of November.  I got in about 1:15 for the buffet.I had Medhu Vada (fried lentil doughnut), onion rings, Veggie Pulav (rice with spice), Coconut rice, Rajma Palek (I believe it was chopped spinach and something chewy), Dal Tadka (yellow lentils, onion and tomato) Paratha bread and a salad.The place has done some cosmetic updates since the last time I was there, quite a bit nicer than it was.  It reminded me much less of a meeting room that had been converted to a restaurant, and quite a bit more like a restaurant.  They did a good job on that.The fried lentil doughnut I got was cold, I am not sure if it was supposed to be room temperature or not, it tasted like moist crumbling bread with a slightly acidic taste.  The onion rings were room temp as well, non-crispy outside breading, but the flavor of the onion was quite striking.  Not something I would eat much of but a nice flavor.The veggie pulav was good, it was a little spicy (I think, had things all mixed up at one point or another) the Dal Tadka lentil concoction was good, but did not pop.  The paratha bread I imagine is good when it's warmer, but it was cold.One of the dishes had suffered a salt overload (I think the cook must have dumped some in the side) so every third or fourth bite was a ton of salt. I do not think this was standard or intentional.The potato pancake appeared later, somehow it always appears when you've had too much food and want to stop.  I don't particularly like the potato pancake, but I do not think that is limited to woodlands.  It was good, as far as unrequested potato pancakes go.The salad.  It may just be that this is the style, but it's the same thing I've always disliked about woodland's... the lettuce tastes like it's ... I don't know, it's not wilted yet, but it's not crisp... the corn in the salad was kind of sweet but tasted a little like it had been boiled and then frozen for a while.  The short of it is I did not like the buffet salad.This particular round on the buffet I was not as disappointed as I've been.  The atmosphere has been upgraded, the food was a little spicier.  I still don't hate the place, but it's really not for me... the buffet seems to lack (at 1:15 on a random Tuesday).For my call-out from Peter K (who also convinced me to go back) I did a quick survey of the ethnicity of the customers, when I went there were no Indian customers, but perhaps that's just because it was 1pm.  2 white people in front of me, behind and to the left.  fairly unpacked at 1:15.I will stand by my original review of the buffet, this style may appeal to you, it may be authentic, but for flavor explosions that appeal to my pallet I go elsewhere.  Your mileage may vary, you will not hate this restaurant and it may be for you. Also as far as I know their non-buffet may rock my socks

reviews.name: Mark F.
reviews.review: Best Indian food I've had since San Fran.

reviews.name: Mark V.
reviews.review: I visit this place regularly and have for a few years. They are kid friendly, they have an amazing buffet at lunch, and the food is intensely flavored. Oh, you can BYOB as they don't serve adult beverages. The prices are very fair and the service is always fantastic.

reviews.name: Sara S.
reviews.review: I was very happy with my experience!  I was kinda skeptical when I heard about it being a vegetarian restaurant (being a vicious carnivore myself) but it was pretty awesome.  Service was good, very friendly guy who helped us decide on dishes.  His English was fairly poor though.  Good atmosphere, not too long of a wait.  I would recommend it!

reviews.name: Janet S.
reviews.review: A-Ok because I finally had a good meal here today.  Channa and spinach curry, $9 dry and chunky.  Order mild so you can still taste the flavor of the food, resteraunts here have a habit of throwing down too much curry powder to get the mild medium hot point across!  Bel puri was a huge portion for $5 and good to split between two. I still do not understand all the 5 stars, indians eat here because there are few options in Nashville and they are all mediocre, same for vegetarians and same for Indian food lovers.  Service was sketchy, they hunt in packs and often miss the target, Parking is tricky at lunch, we got the last spot.  Overall today a nice dining experience but the company was better than the food.  Dosas are good but then its hard to mess them up.  Buffet good value $10 and a reasonable choice.

reviews.name: Cassie K.
reviews.review: When my husband and I travel we always try out an indian restaurant in the area. We did not regret making Woodlands our choice. Indian AND vegetarian?! It was a match made in heaven. The food tasted great and they don't use heavy creams so it didn't leave us feeling too full as many indian restaurants can do.

reviews.name: Simon K.
reviews.review: After ordering their eggplant dish and their mushroom marsala, it made me think about how easy it could be as vegetarian.  Then I started thinking about the word "vegetarian" and how similar it was to the word "planetarium," and then I thought about what it would be like having a strict diet of eating planets only...  and that's the closest I ever got to becoming a vegetarian.Well that train of thought didn't make sense, but the food at Woodlands does.  Ordinarily I would recommend the lunch buffet because it's such a good deal, but Woodlands really shines during their dinner menu.  Their dosas are delicious, and they do a great job of making their entrees so tasty that you forget about needing meat to make your meal complete (unintentional rhyme).  Service is what you would expect.  The only criticism I have is how dark the restaurant is.  Take it from a Asian who's already self-conscience about his eyes... I don't like squinting at my food in public.  But all in all, it's a great restaurant.

reviews.name: Jennifer J.
reviews.review: Let me start by saying I never write reviews and this place was so good I felt compelled. I have never tried Indian food before I went to this restaurant but wanted to give it a try. I really liked the fact that the restaurant is very vegan friendly also. I ordered the Gobi Manchurian (Dry) as an appetizer per another reviewers suggestion and was so glad I did. It was fantastic. I will be going back for that alone. We also ordered the appetizer sampler and my favorite things on there were the vegetable samosas and vegetable pakora. We split the special spring dosa and dal makhani and both were delicious. Although everything was wonderful two of us ordered enough food to feed four people easily. The dosas are huge so beware. I would highly recommend this place even if you do like meat.

reviews.name: Megha M.
reviews.review: This is a great place for authentic Indian food !  Being an Indian I frequently crave Indian food and this is my go to place for authentic Indian food . I've been going there for over a year now and have never been disappointed . The only drawback is they do not have any meat options but the veggie options are plenty and enough to keep me going back. The lunch buffet is the best way to try a lot of different things. I love their Sambhar (lentils) and their idli (rice cakes). The service is good too although they get really busy on weekends for the lunch hour.The price for the buffet is about $10 and if you order ala-carte the total shouldn't really exceed $15.

reviews.name: Chad R.
reviews.review: I am a carnivore by nature but there are times when I love to enjoy a good vegetarian food.  I also love Indian cuisine.  Woodlands is a great place for lovers of vegetarian Indian food.  Its tucked on West End Avenue on the ground floor of a high rise building and can be a bit hard to find for those who have never visited there previously.  Its located near I-440 and is across the street from a convenience store.  The restaurant itself is a mid-sized space but is very tastefully and nicely decorated and furnished.  It really provides for a nice, relaxing atmosphere.  The food is always delicious. I have had a wide variety of their entrees, soups, breads, and desserts and it is wonderful across the board.  Its probably the best place to eat vegetarian Indian food.  If you want to try a variety of foods, then go there to partake of their lunch buffet which is excellent.   Its a great place to go by yourself or with friends and has always provided me with a great meal and a good time.  The only downside is parking is very limited.  If you go there for lunch, then you had better go early because the parking lot can get full quickly.  However, I am told that there is parking behind the building too.

reviews.name: Amanda G.
reviews.review: Woodlands is by far my favorite restaurant in Nashville. The flavors are in perfect balance with one another. My only problem is that every time I go there I always order the dosa. Luckily my boyfriend tries something else so I can taste some of what he is getting as well. With that said each dosa I have tried has been different. If you have never tried one than I strongly suggest that you do. They are the perfect combination of flavors and texture. Giant sourdough like crepes filled with spicy vegetables and served with delicious sauces. Some people I have talked to have been concerned with the restaurant being completely vegetarian. Don't let this stop you from going. You won't miss the meat. The food is hearty and filling. The samosas are also really great. Some of the best that I've had. They serve it with green chutney which I wish they served with everything else. I'm addicted to that stuff. The chili pakoras are also great. But watch out, they are really spicy!

reviews.name: Owen W B.
reviews.review: A little difficult to get in and out of but pretty good food. Not the friendliest service but not bad either. Food is good even for a lunch buffet.

reviews.name: Caitlin C.
reviews.review: I am not a vegetarian and my favorite indian dish is chicken tikka masala...so I must admit I was disappointed when I heard vegetarian. But the wonderful thing about Indian food, is it is the vegetarians dream! And Woodlands is killer!We went for the lunch buffet and it is jamming...they have more than several options and every single thing I tried I liked. I apologize to those who ate after our party of 8 because I'm pretty sure we cleared the place of samosas, which were particularly good dipped in their tamarind sauce. We had a few folks who had never eaten Indian and I realize an Indian buffet is a good way to introduce someone. They can try little bits of everything and not get scared away entirely. So I would definitely recommend the buffet if you're introducing Indian food to a noob. BUT get there early...seriously...you know a place is good if they make small batches of food and they're liable to run out of one thing before they bring out anothe dish.I'm coming back...I'd like to try their Garlic Naan.

reviews.name: Eliza R.
reviews.review: I went to Woodlands for a late lunch buffet one Saturday and was delighted by the selection of delicious, authentic vegetarian Indian food they offered.  I can't remember exactly what I ate, but it was all tasty!

reviews.name: Devin P.
reviews.review: So some friends of mine decided to take me and my girlfriend out for dinner,they asked if we have ever been to Woodland's reply was "no." They then asked if we liked Indian food,our reply was "are you F'in kidding us?!"   Since we had never been before we stuck to dishes we would usually order elsewhere. This being said we started with the veggie samosa which was very well prepared!  for dinner I had the Special Spring Dosa which was very good!   one thing I didn't find to true was the fact of the spiciness,they asked how I like my "heat" I said VERY!! In turn it wasn't thus only giving them 4 outta 5 stars.  I will return and then some and recommend highly!

reviews.name: Ashwin M.
reviews.review: With great sadness I must confess that Woodlands has slowly yet steadily dropped in its quality. As a rule of thumb, I avoid an Indian restaurant that serves lunch buffet. If you think about it, the economy of scale begs them to use the same base sauce for everything and use the leftovers for dinner a la carte. This is what I have begun to observe. Their dinners have steadily dropped in taste. The deep fried appetizers (pakodas, samosas, etc) are bland. Even cardboard tastes better. Their north Indian fare is no match to the almighty Bombay Palace right down the road. Their idlis, a staple south Indian fare, and something that I am used to having piping hot fresh from the stoves, is mostly stale and microwaved. Their only saving grace is their the UFO-sized Channa Batura and their dosas (rice crepes). Barring this, Woodlands is merely riding on their established credo and, like Apple, are doomed to fail after being famous for just their name.
