reviews.name: Brian N.
reviews.review: Woodlands could almost change my mind about being a carnivore, lol, almost.This is honestly one of the most flavorful places I eat around town. Each dish is packed with so much spice and flavor it's amazing. Everything seems so fresh and tasty you don't miss the fact that there is no meat on the menu. their samosas and dosas are both always delicious and of course my favorite dessert the gulab jamun is fantastic.I really could go on and on about this place, the tastes, textures, spices, chutneys, they're all very wonderful. Do yourself a favor and stop in sometime. The staff is always very attentive and friendly.This is definitely on my top 5 places to grab a quick delicious lunch.

reviews.name: Lisa J.
reviews.review: Such good food with variety and good prices.  There is quite a bit of indian food in Nashville but this has definitely been the best.  They have the not widely available dishes from south india and a lot of indian street food too.  It is a great affordable and unassuming place.

reviews.name: Ruiqiu K.
reviews.review: I am hardly a vegetarian. But I am a fan of eggplant.I had a hankering for something Asian-ish, with rice. And it was too hot to walk more than a block. I remember seeing this place when I was exiting Dairy Queen the other day.I was disappointed that they were vegetarian, as I really wanted some protein at the time. But, after a quick perusal of their menu online, I knew I had to try their baingan bartha (eggplant / tomato curry). I placed a to-go order, walked 5 minutes, and was stunned that my dish was ready when I got there. I had even brought a book with me, in the off chance that I would be waiting during their lunch rush.The guy who gave me the order was so nice. I really only expected a fork and napkins, but he added a (styrofoam) plate, as well.The steamed white rice was plain, but fluffy. (Where I'm from, more and more places offer brown rice even if the cuisine doesn't normally use it.) The side of raita was small, but delicious, (If I were settled in, I would normally dump a lot of my homemade yogurt into my takeout Indian dishes because I'm a wimp when it comes to spicy food). And the baingan bartha was divine. It was just what I expected to taste. I was glad that I asked for mild -- it was still spicy, but not at a level that I couldn't handle. Maybe I'm just eating less because of the heat, but the portion was enough for me to make 4 meals out of this (albeit I have to make more rice).I am intrigued that their menu offers "Indo-Chinese" food. I know there are Muslim Chinese restaurants in San Francisco and in Las Vegas. So I am surprised to see an actual ethnic fusion cuisine in Nashville that I had yet to see in more diverse cities.

reviews.name: Jamie A.
reviews.review: 100th review!Not the best I've had, but pretty darn tasty.  We double dated here with some friends (after I promised my boyfriend that I'd buy him a burger if he didn't enjoy the vegetarian fare).  Thankfully, that was not necessary!We started with the Woodland's Special Rava Masala dosa.  It was freaking incredible!  Garlic naan was tasty dunked in raita.  Mattar Paneer was decent.  The Vegetable Koorma my boyfriend ordered was tasty, he ate it all. The overwhelming star of the meal was the Malai Kofta.  It was in this decadent cashew sauce.  We finished our meals with the best Galub Jamun I've had.  My issue w/ the food is that everything was extremely mild.  Next time I will order my curry hot.

reviews.name: Joanna F.
reviews.review: Mmmmm..... So good. This definitely satisfied my Indian craving for that night. I came here with a friend who had only one other experience with Indian food and that was several years ago. It can be hard to miss. It's located right beside a hotel that is right off I-440. I missed it the first time.I ordered the Dal Makhani with Rice (Kidney beans,yellow and black lentil cooked with onion, tomato & spices), which was about $9. I also got some plain naan and the mango lassi. The Dal Makhani was really tasty, and I ate almost all of it. I think I would have like it more if there was more spices in it. The mango lassi was delicious and great way to end the dinner, but it was really sweet. I would have been satisfied with drinking half of it. My friends thought it was very delicious.My friend ordered a dosa. I forgot what kind though... We were expecting a little crepe, ya know. But this huge, bigger-than-yo-face crepe came out. We were surprised. I only had a little taste, but boy-oh-boy, was it yummmmmyyy!The only real complaint I have was that I feel they were trying to rush us out as we were getting close to dinner. Two or three times we were asked, "Do you need a to-go-box?" Um... Not yet.Aside from that, service is good. Food is delicious. Lighting is a little too dim. And I'm coming back for a dosa sometime soon!

reviews.name: Em S.
reviews.review: Possibly the best Indian restaurant and the best vegetarian restaurant in Tennessee! For those who are unfamiliar with southern Indian cuisine, and even for those who are, the lunch buffet ($8.99, seven days a week) is a fantastic value for the wallet and even better treat for the belly. There are salads and fruits, cold yogurts, sauces, two soups, two desserts, breads, and a handful of different hot dishes, many of which go beyond the normal samosa and curry. Just when you think you've loaded up on the yummy food, the waiter will bring out a fresh dosa for each person at the table - it's like a crepe, with a small stuffing of potato inside. The only problem is wishing you had more room in your stomach! Dinner service (yes, I've been here multiple times) is refined and elegant, yet very affordable, and just as delicious as the buffet. There is a side room that can accommodate large parties.Service is also wonderful, with pleasant and responsive wait staff. The biggest complaint (and it's not very big) is some people find the location more difficult to see the first time, as it is on the ground floor of a condo building, but it's definitely not hard to get to, right off I-440, minutes from Vanderbilt, Belle Meade, and even downtown, well worth the trip, even if it takes waiting for the MTA buses that run down West End!

reviews.name: Catriona C.
reviews.review: So I came out last year. Well, more the fact of meat out, veggies and fish in. After years of dithering, I realised that I simply had to be true to myself and reject that, that wasn't. I'm four weeks in and I am wondering if I am breaking. Mainly because I am on a work trip to the south and have discovered that I can eat bugger all. I may have built up my own body weight in heavy metal from all the fish I have eaten due to the utter lack of vegetarian options on most menus, and when there are hundreds of meat-based options, I feel like I am wavering, just to get some damn choice. One of things I hadn't attempted since my conversion was to try out a vegetarian restaurant. Don't ask me why - but something scared me about such places. But tonight, faced with yet another night of optionless meals, I went for it and yelped Nashville for vegetarian options - and Woodlands came up. First up was a vegetable samosa platter - essentially, unlike the samosas I have had in the past, these were slices of vegetables fried in a thick almost-pastry like batter. A little dry and heavy for my tastes and overall, rather tasteless, with sauces that neither complimented nor provided detriment to them. Then I had the Bombay Bhaji - mooshed up vegetables, with rice, mango chutney and a lemon raita. Bonus points - my server asked what spice level I wanted - honestly it was a bit too spicy for me, but if I go again, I will know to ask for a more mild version. So at a guess I would say in my veggie mash there was tomatoes, onion, non-mooshed peas and potato - anything else, I couldn't tell you - but it did taste cliantro/spicy infused goodness. The lemon raita was a great addition, but the mango chutney was way too bitter for my tastes. The bhaji was also perfect for naan-dipping - which was a little over toasted and not as fluffy as I would like. Overall, I enjoyed my meal at Woodlands - although I would say that a lot of the meals were centred around potatoes more than I would like. And it was nice to be absolutely spoiled for choice rather than scrabbling desperately around for a change.

reviews.name: Steph H.
reviews.review: It's not like this place really needs another 5-star review, since they've got so many already, but they deserve it so I'm giving it to them anyway!It used to be that Nashville had few decent Indian options, but with Woodlands and Bombay Palace, you've pretty much got all you need. Woolands focuses on Southern Indian food, which tends to be vegetarian, and as such the restaurant sticks to serving up dishes using ingredients that never had a pulse. Bombay Palace does Northern Indian cuisine that tends to be saucier and richer, and yes, involves meat. So if you put these two restaurants in your arsenal, you're all set.I love the 7-day/week buffets at both places, but I admit that when it comes to waiter/table service, I think I prefer Woodlands. The prices are super reasonable, and the menu is so fun. I love the dosas (thin crispy pancakes that are filled with various items... think Indian crepes),  which are potentially worth ordering just for the crave-worthy coconut sauce that accompanies them. Often just the thought of Indian food can make you feel heavy and bogged down, but I never feel anything but pleasantly full after dining at Woodlands. The food is so good that you truly don't miss the meat - my husband is a dedicated and resolute omnivore and even he never passes up a chance to dine here.The staff is always very friendly and helpful and service is speedy. The food is always fresh (even during the buffet) and the cleanliness of the restaurant is top notch (always something I worry about at buffets). Woodlands has recently done some renovations and gussied up the dining room, so it truly is a wonderful place to enjoy a meal. Here's a tip to help you get the most of the experience: Woodlands is BYO, so if you feel like imbibing anything other than kid friendly sodas, mango lassies, or teas/coffees, you can bring your own alcohol of choice with you.

reviews.name: Whitney B.
reviews.review: This was my first purely vegetarian Indian restaurant I have visited outside of India. I know they exist, but they are hard to find. I came around lunch time and the place was packed. The staff were all friendly, but one of them had on way too much cologne. I ordered samosas and baingan bharta with a couple pieces of chapatis.The samosa was delicious, and I had one left over, which I ate for breakfast the next day, cold. Even cold it was nice. The bb was heaven. I could probably eat it every day. The chapatis were good, but not my favorite. What is cool is that this place specializes in Dosas. I really wanted one, because I fell in love with them in India... but the last time I had one was when I was sick. And I haven't been able to look at one ever since. But it was very tempting. Oh so tempting.

reviews.name: Jess Y.
reviews.review: I really wanted to like Woodlands more than I did.  My friends had hyped me up about the food and I love Indian food, so I was so excited to finally make a visit.  But, when it comes down to it, I still prefer Bombay Palace over Woodlands--and I'm not saying this just because I'm an omnivore and appreciate meat, really! (Although, I do enjoy my meat)First off, for those of you who are driving, it's right next to the hotel. But, you do not need to actually enter the hotel to enter the restaurant. My friends and I unfortunately realized this the hard way, when one of them decided to ring the bell for service to enter the hotel.  When we realized that the entrance to the restaurant was just to the left, we quickly sneaked away, hoping not to be noticed.That aside, the lunch buffet is pretty spacious (when you compare it to Bombay Palace--also the space is significantly easier to navigate--Bombay Palace's buffet area is like one small walk-in closet).  There is a good selection of different foods to taste.  The rice was fantastic as was a spinach/cheese dish--one of my favorites.  They also offer dosas, similar to Bombay Palace, which are kind of like crepes with lentil/potato/something-delicious filled inside.  My dining party and I had a whole argument about whether they were filled with lentils or potatoes. I still contend that there were potatoes inside--although, my research on Wiki says that the crepe part does include crushed lentils. Either way, they are delicious.  Unlike Bombay Palace, they also offer Puri which are the really thin, crispy breads.  Side note, I love Indian breads. Also they had some other interesting things like a lentil donut and a sweet cinnamon shredded carrot dessert.They also offered a cauliflower dish that was called a curry, but I'm not sure why. It was pretty amazing how they got the cauliflower to have a meat-like texture, but it created some cognitive conflict in my mouth when it had the exact texture and flavor of General Tso's Chicken. It was bizarre and I'm not sure if that's a good thing.The food is pretty good, but I think Bombay Palace's is better. It just seems more flavorful--maybe that has more to do with the Northern/Southern cuisine differences. I don't know enough about Indian cuisine to decide. But, all I can say is that I've enjoyed my dining experiences at other Indian restaurants more.

reviews.name: Will W.
reviews.review: We can be a choosy lot when it comes to Indian cuisine. A friend told us that this was THE place for Indian food in Nashville, and it was superb.The mixed veg and palak paneer dishes is delicious, the pakora is thick with spiced chana flower, the naan is crispy and fluffy, and the staff is exceptionally nice. Prices are totally reasonable, and it's BYOB.

reviews.name: Tj D.
reviews.review: The lunch buffet is excellent...nice variety of dishes for a great price.

reviews.name: Pritish Z.
reviews.review: So, finally I went for lunch buffet today and overall, I liked it and would rate it 8/10. I started off with some Bread (Nan), Spinach Curry, Paneer Butter Masala and their traditional sambar. I liked the Spinach curry as it was really tasty and fresh. On the other hand, Paneer Butter Masala was not that great but still I managed to finish everything I got in my plate. Later on, I tried their traditional food (south indian) and today they served Idli (white in color), mandu wada (kind of round shaped similar to donut but not sweet!) and dosa. All the three items were pretty good and yummy (but I loved "Idli").  To my surprise, they had Pan Puri (one of food you will find a lot in Western part of India) and it was awesome! Now can we complete our lunch without desserts? Off course not!They had a variety of desserts in the buffet: Gulab Jamun, Sweet Yogurt, Fruit Salad. I grabbed four gulab jamun in a bowl (b'coz I loveeee it!) and it was so fresh that I almost thought of going for another 4 (but i didn't). Sweet yogurt was kind of ok. But that Gulab Jamun made my day! Overall, I would recommend to give it a try and don't forget to get the desserts (plz get 1 gulab jamun on my behalf .. LOL!). N-JoyyY!

reviews.name: Sabra E.
reviews.review: I adore Indian Food, and I'm always looking for good quality Indian buffets since you can sample a little of everything. This place has it! Even if you love meat....you won't be disappointed with the Vegetarian selection. The Dosa is delicious!! I was too full to try the Mango Lassi, but many others were drinking them. Maybe next time....Go check it out!

reviews.name: Raquel M.
reviews.review: I went to the lunch buffet everything was delicious and there was a wonderful assortment of dishes to choose from.

reviews.name: Cara W.
reviews.review: This place is wonderful,  I go out of my way to come to the lunch here every time I'm in Nashville.  The food is always warm, fresh and delicious.  I tend to shy away from buffets but this one always seems clean.  There's always a huge variety of options.

reviews.name: Ian R.
reviews.review: First off I am not a Vegetarian, I have equal love for meat and veg and usually try to keep the two in pretty good ratio.  Woodlands is honestly a place where meat is not needed.  Food is food, if it tastes good and is made with care then who cares what it is made from.  Woodlands definitely provides quality food and it should be in the running for best Indian food in Nashville.  For vegetarians it must be one of the highlights of Nashville dining and even meat lovers could walk away from Woodlands feeling extremely satisfied with the meal.      This is an abbreviated review because I have only had the lunch buffet.  The good thing about the buffet is you get to try a wide variety of dishes and they are all excellent.  They even bring out a mini dosa to go with the buffet (not actually small, but compared the the full size it is still a  mini).  It is also a very good deal for the quality of food and the competition in town.  I hope to go back for dinner and try some more items on the menu and add a star.   For now this will have to remain a four star review, but with high hopes for more.

reviews.name: Kathleen K.
reviews.review: Oh man... I've been putting off trying this place for a while, and I'm glad I finally did. I cook curry at home a lot and tend not to like the typical butter- and cream-soaked North Indian places around town, but I was blown away by this place. Skip the pakoras - they're good, but it's worth saving room for the pani puris, which are delicious and fun to eat. For entrees we had a masala dosa, vegetable korma, and palak paneer. The dosa was hot and crispy, and the curries were great - full of fresh flavor and balance. The dishes were all moderately spicy without being at all overwhelming.The condiments really stood out as well - the lemon pickle alongside the curries and the coconut chutney alongside the dosa are like nothing else you'll find in an Indian restaurant in Nashville. They don't serve alcohol, but it's BYOB, and there is no corkage fee. I'm an omnivore and love meat and seafood curries, but the food is just so good here, you won't miss the meat one bit. I only wish I'd had room for dessert too.

reviews.name: Katrina V.
reviews.review: This place is amazing...and in Tennessee, of all places.  I wish this place would pick up and move to California, haha.The lunch buffet here is AWESOME.  We got there just a few minutes after opening and there were already a bunch of people there--a good sign.  You could tell these were regulars that came to the buffet often.  This isn't like one of those huge buffets with 200 items..they keep it small and simple and DELICIOUS.  I went two days in a row and the items were different, too.  This place is, seriously, a real gem.

reviews.name: Emily M.
reviews.review: Today at lunch, I asked "why don't I come here more often?". The answer is:  because I don't want to feel 'lazy'. I love the Woodlands lunch buffet. Today I came in my sweats, because I happen to live right upstairs. I guess I just take Woodlands for granted, and I should make more of an effort to eat at this great place!Other than ten stars for convenience, I give Woodlands five stars because:The food is fresh and delicious, the people who work there are very friendly, and the atmosphere is casual and comfortable (and clean).If you are not familiar with Indian food, try the lunch buffet. You get a great sample of various foods, soups, and sweet treats... and can have a small (or large) taste of everything. I picked up a copy of their new dinner menu, and I can't wait to try their new entrees!

reviews.name: Kay Z.
reviews.review: Most wonderful Indian food in Nashville.  Don't even bother with any other restaurant.  They buffet is so clean and the service is always wonderful.  Nice variety of food and soups.  The Carrot Halwa is PHENOMENAL!  I DESPISE curry but no worries, there is usually only one curry dish.  The food is so fresh and good, no need for the meat, you are full hours later.  HIGHLY reccomend

reviews.name: Chef X.
reviews.review: It's very good, especially when you want something other than Sitar which is also very good.  Man we're lucky! Not one but two tasty Indian restaurants inside The Loop.Okay Chinese restaurant people-see? it's not that hard.

reviews.name: Heather H.
reviews.review: This isn't a review I want to write, but one that I hope brings awareness for the staff and diners.I have some family in town, and we all adhere to some form of vegetarianism, so the first place I thought to take them was Woodlands-it has the most variety, good service, and reasonable prices. One of my cousins has had bad reactions to the food at some Chinese restaurants, and has theorized MSG was the culprit, if not something else. As a routine, she asks about it in any new restaurants.  As soon as we walked in the door, we asked the host if they used MSG, or any other additives or allergens. He said to steer clear of the Indochina section. Beyond that he wasn't exactly reassuring, and I felt, a bit dismissive. We sat down and ordered drinks. I looked to my left and saw a cockroach on the drapes. Horrified, but not surprised given the type of building Woodlands is in, I let it go because the food is good enough to deal. That and I didn't feel like driving to Sitar. I ordered the chana palak. The spinach was undercooked and I found a bay leaf in it. I also asked for spicy but the dish was bland, so I had to ask for chili on the side. It was disappointing overall and I left most of it on the plate. So the meal was wrapping up and my cousin got up and walked outside. She returned a few minutes later with a look of panic and tears in her eyes and said her throat was closing up. We paid, and explained that she was having a bad reaction to the food. The host looked alarmed, and I hope he remembers what happened. It pays to understand the ingredients your own restaurant works with! Please, do some simple research, so whether it was an additive or a common food allergen, you can know what to tell people who ask about them. Luckily Vandy was nearby, and we went straight to the ER. Meds and a handful of hours of observation later, all was back to normal. As for me, this was a one off bad experience at Woodlands and I'll be back, but I hope, sincerely, that the infestation, meal prep, and most importantly, allergen awareness is dealt with quickly.

reviews.name: Brandon S.
reviews.review: Giant frisbee sized dosas and no corking fee.  That's right, you can bring in as much alcohol as you'd like and slurp it down while eating Dosas- which brings me to the next important piece of this review.  Dosa: a 2X2 foot, flat-bread-like crepe.  Delicious and only $8 or so. Missing a star because the dishes are not 5-star quality.  Even so, it's the best indian food I've found in Nashville.

reviews.name: Susan W.
reviews.review: I have been here for both lunch and dinner. I enjoyed both of my experience here. They offer wide variety from noodles to rice to pancake dishes.

reviews.name: Tressa P.
reviews.review: Lunch or dinner, this is my favorite place to eat in Nashville. Has really been a challenge for me to keep it to two visits a week on account of their amazing food and unobtrusive, friendly service.The lunch buffet is a great way to try it all. They don't always offer naan so keep your mind open to other bread possibilities like poori, paratha or roti~ all tasty!I've noticed a few people are confused regarding the flow around the buffet and I'm here to help- clockwise is the proper direction.

reviews.name: Sarah R.
reviews.review: How did I know I was in for a great meal? Ninety percent of the customers in Woodlands were Indian. That is always a good sign.  The flavors were complex and balanced. The menu is massive, but in my experience, it seems that everything they do, they do well.The huge homemade samosas were a big standout. Portions were generous. The staff was pleasant and friendly. The food was very reasonably priced ($8.50 for a curry). I can't wait to come back and try the buffet; it seems they shut it down around 2:30pm, so we missed it.Woodlands loses a star because the atmosphere suffers due to really ugly decor. Consequently, it could never be a great first date spot. But if you're going out for a meal with someone you know already loves you, it's a great choice.

reviews.name: Alan R.
reviews.review: Best place in Nashville to go for a veggie pig-out!!!!!!

reviews.name: Jessica M.
reviews.review: LOVE THIS PLACE. My boyfriend and I come to Woodlands on a regular basis. This place has a great selection of vegetarian food and for a great price! We usually hit up the lunch buffet, which is busy but delicious! One of my favorite spots for great food.

reviews.name: Amy M.
reviews.review: For full disclosure, I will say that I am a vegetarian. However, I am also quite familiar with Indian food and do not take the process of rating an Indian restaurant lightly. True, mediocre Indian is usually better than the best version of, well, almost any other cuisine in my book. But Woodlands earned this 5 of 5 fair and square.The menu is extensive and features South Indian, North Indian and Indo-Chinese, the latter of which I did not sample. I got iddly (steamed rice/lentil patties) for an appetizer and delighted in the large portions of coconut chutney and sambar that accompanied them. My sister-in-law ordered a dosa and it was frighteningly large, with the filling on the side in a metal bowl. I ordered palak paneer and my brother had the aloo gobi, both of which were delicious, aromatic and well-spiced. Raita (yogurt sauce) and lemon pickle were also included with the meal.I'm going to be moving from Gainesville, FL to Nashville in a few months and I'm really glad that I will be able to overstuff myself at Woodlands again soon.

reviews.name: Gregory R.
reviews.review: Chaat Chaat Chaat Chaat!! All the food is great here, but make sure you check out the chaat and indo-chinese dishes. The usual common Indian dishes that you can get anywhere else in town are fine, but the real stars here are the things you can't get anywhere else. We were lucky to get a good introduction from fellow Yelper Ashwin M. who ordered a variety of things for the whole table that were all amazing. The puris are oh so good. Paani puri is my favorite and fun to make and eat, too. A drop of this, a dollop of that, some spicy water and devour before it saturates the puff! The Woodlands Special Rava Masala Dosa is another favorite, but they are all great. Uthappas are super, too. Definitely a regular stop in our Nashville restaurant rotation.

reviews.name: Kim U.
reviews.review: I'm not a vegetarian and in general I hate buffets, but the food at Woodlands is delicious. I've only been there for lunch. Really need to go for dinner, because I'd prefer to order off a menu instead of the lunch buffet. Great variety on the lunch buffet, lots of really tasty dishes. They also brought two filled crepe items directly to our table and those were awesome (didn't have a chance to ask what they were though). Best mango lassi I've ever had, too. Get there early for lunch - we arrived at 11:45 and it was practically empty. By the time we left sometime around 12:15-12:30, every table was full. Give this place a try, even if you're not a vegetarian!Location note: it is a little tricky to get to, especially if traffic is heavy. There's a large silver building at 3401 West End and Woodlands is located in the apartment building directly next to that, on the south side of the street.

reviews.name: Maya L.
reviews.review: Great lunch buffet! There are always several different waiters refilling your water and aimlessly milling around, but the food quickly arrives to your table. Plenty of vegan and gluten-free options, jut ask your waiter!

reviews.name: Glen C.
reviews.review: We stopped here whilst passing through Nashville eastbound, and it was great.  The food was really well done, waitstaff were extremely polite and helpful, and it is unbelievably cheap for what you get.  This place could probably afford to charge $$$ prices for what they're doing, so you are getting a great deal eating here.Only thing is, the place is not easy to spot.  No real signage that you're going to see from the street, it's basically in the front of a big hotel or office block or something, the last big building as you're driving towards the big freeway entrance that's around there.  We had to loop around a couple times but got there in the end.Highly recommended if you're in the area.

reviews.name: Eric B.
reviews.review: i think this is my favorite restaurant in the entire city. my goodness, do i love you, woodlands.eric b

reviews.name: Jimmy M.
reviews.review: Best Indian food in Nashville hands down!!! My wife and I went here about a week ago and loved it. The food was phenomenal and the waitstaff were very courteous and friendly. The restaurant is at the bottom of the Colonial apartments/condos and was kind of hard to find if you aren't paying a lot of attention. The decor was really nice and the restaurant was very clean. One thing that really impressed me was the wide selection of food and then how delicious and inexpensive everything was, if you are in the Nashville area and love or want to try some outstanding Indian food you can't miss out on this place!!!!

reviews.name: Michelle M.
reviews.review: Amazing Indian food. Again, AMAZING food. Great for vegetarians. I cannot say enough wonderful things about the food. They also serve chaat, which I have not found at many places in Nashville. The decor leaves a little to be desired, but who cares about decor when you are stuffing your face with THE BEST FOOD EVER. When my husband (who is a meat and potatoes kind of guy, who doesn't usually enjoy vegetarian) and I discovered this place, we went back 2 times in one week. We've been back since then, and will keep going back again. Yummy, yummy food!

reviews.name: Danielle B.
reviews.review: I was driving through Nashville and had a couple of recommendations for this place. As a vegan, I was worried about the number of choices I would have to choose  from. My worry was needless!Immediately upon arrival I was seated and given a cold glass of water. The server was able to answer all of my *many* questions and guide me through my selection effortlessly. The food was quick to arrive and was wonderfully delicious? The nice thing was that I wanted heat and I got it! It was just right...I left with open sinuses for the first time in a while!There was more than enough food. I ordered a combination dinner that came with many courses (the buffet was not open at the time). Unfortunately I am unable to recall the names of the dishes I ordered but the taste was spot on and the price was right. I have nothing negative to post other than I was too full to try anything else. Oh well, you win some, you lose some, lol. I highly recommend you give this place a shot. I know I can't wait to travel back through Nashville again!*note: I had to circle around in order to find the entrance...it is located in a busy section and I saw the restaurant just a little too late to catch it the first time. Other than that, no problem!

reviews.name: Cynthia F.
reviews.review: Loved the lunch buffet.  Inexpensive; fresh cooking.  Not all Indian lunch buffets offer  a variety of tasty desserts, which are my favorite part.  The fresh orange slices were a surprise and a refreshing, welcome treat to cleanse the palate after the spicy entrees.  I loved the fact that everything was vegetarian so I didn't have to ask a million questions.  A warning to those on a tight budget: soft drinks ordered with meals might  NOT be included in the buffet price.

reviews.name: Lucy M.
reviews.review: Indian food is easily one of my favorite cuisines, but I've never been much for vegetarian Indian! Woodlands is the perfect place if you like me. There aren't many Indian joint practically anywhere that specialize in Dosa. And dear sweet Visnu, is Dosa delicious. Much to my happiness, I can see I'm not alone on this. If you're looking for something unique to add to your already satisfying meal, I suggest Bathura (pronounced "Battura"). It's a giant inflated dome of fried bread for dipping in your curries or what have yous. It shaped kind of like a giant clam, and the size could house a teenaged cat. I've never had a bad experience here. Going to the Woodlands is of absolute necessity when I take a visit to Nashville. Someday I think I'll try to high five the chef. That man is a genius.

reviews.name: Megan T.
reviews.review: My vegetarian friend brought me here for a quick din-din one night. As soon as I walked in I thought, "Man, if there are Indian families eating dinner here then it's good enough for me!". Honestly, how many Chinese people have you seen ordering take-out on a friday night? Yeeeaaah, that's my point. I have heard that Indians don't eat a whole lot of meat anyway, so my best guess is that the most authentic dishes really are meat free. (I have to say that I have never been to India, but it's on my bucket list.) I let X-tine order for me, I just wanted something spicy... mmmm. So we ended up getting a lot of cheesy dishes, two variations on paneer (cheese cubes in curry) Some veggies fried in a batter, and some lentle soup. My absolute fav was the lentle dish, being lactose intolerant can interfere with my ability to enjoy cheese so I won't go there on the paneer.The naan was delish, but my only complaint is that they only give you one slice per person :( If you want more, you have to pay another $3 something. I usually like to fill up on the nan and raita. And it's always nice to have a bit of naan to go with your left overs. Next time I will hit up the buffet, it sounds like you get a better deal. But over all the food was quality!

reviews.name: Peter C.
reviews.review: Love Indian cuisine, but unfortunately every trip ended up being slightly guilt-ridden because of the obvious-this-is-not-low-fat-ness of the foods.  To remedy this, I decided to try Woodlands, hailed as "the best Indian food in town" by my Indian friends (all 3 of them).  Kind of an unusual set up at the first floor of an apartment building, the inside is lushly decorated.  The street-food appetizers are amusing and delicous, but I a head-over-heels over the chickpea curry.  It is SO GOOD!!  Taste, substance, aroma... really triggers something deep inside (in a good way).  It is still not low-fat, but at least it is vegetarian and beyond delicous.

reviews.name: Oliver G.
reviews.review: Great food all vegetarian definitely try the soups on the buffet.

reviews.name: Will M.
reviews.review: Good for dinner, just ok for lunch.  BYOB.  Samosas.. yes in the green sauce.  I'll stop describing at the risk of sounding dumb.  Come here for Indian food.  A little on the less spicy side.

reviews.name: Mariela C.
reviews.review: Being a self proclaimed meat-i-vore Woodlands vegetarian cuisine didn't sound like the kind of place that 'my kind' frequented. A random act of faith, however, led me to Woodlands and a genuinely pleasant surprise. To satiate its highly eclectic patrons, Woodlands menu is full well priced plates that sound appetizing even to a meat lover as myself. My first visit to Woodlands, I timidly ordered the Potato Bonda off the appetizer menu. A mix of potatoes, spices, and fried goodness, the Potato Bonda not only spoke to me, but also ended up being absolutely delicious! Having erroneously anticipated not liking Woodlands, I had had a pre-lunch lunch, that prevented me from ordering more of the menu, but needless to say I intend to return to see what else Woodlands has to offer. The wait staff was really friendly and the atmosphere great. If anything the idea of being surrounded by the smell of a great assortment of spice should get you to try it out.In case you are perplexed by its location, and are concerned by the fact that all you can find is an apartment/office building at its given address, don't worry you have in fact arrived. Located at the bottom of a not so inconspicuous building, you might not be wowed by its décor, but you will definitely find great food.

reviews.name: Crabby O.
reviews.review: I'm torn between three and four stars for these guys.I've eaten the lunch buffet here several times. I am not a vegetarian so I can't fully appreiciate this place. Having said that I wished they would serve soome dishes that have a little more substance (beans, lentils, eggplant, chickpeas, peas, cheese, etc.) . There is way too much starch - even many of the vegetable dishes are very heavy on the potatoes (the vegetable korma resembles coconut and potato soup). Perhaps this is a regional thing but prepare yourself for bread,potatoes, rice, bread, potatoes, rice.....The food quality is good. One compaint would be that a lot of the dishes taste too similar and don't have much character of their own. Very mild for Southern Indian food. Very mild. The must have item there is the Puri - soft and delictable. The raita is very, very good but I wouldn't recommend the dahi vada (I found it inedible). They bring dosas to your table, they have a great texture but a tad bland for my taste.If you are put off by the hotness of Indian food, try this place.On last thing the iced tea is gross. I don;t know what they do to it but it is awful. I usually love the iced tea at Indian joints this stuff taste like it was brewed with leaves from a hackberry or something,

reviews.name: Chris W.
reviews.review: I've always said that Indian food is the only saving grace that would allow me to be a vegetarian. Woodlands is a splendid demonstration of that fact.I can only speak to the lunch buffet, as I've never been for dinner (need to rectify this soon). It's a staple of my office's lunchtime rotation. I've been a half-dozen times, and it's never disappointed once.There are some staples, like the chana palak, that are consistently awesome. They rotate some things in and out as well.. Last time I was there I had a surprisingly good concoction -- some sort of beet curry. The rasam soup is easily one of my favorites. They're generous with the dosas, and they are tasty as well.I've been to a lot of the local Nashville Indian favorites, but they have tended to be slightly dull or more tailored for an American palate. Not this place. Last week I went to a place near San Jose that was touted as a pretty top-notch place, and you know what? It had nothing on Woodlands.Only gripe is its location, which is in an area that can be a bit of a traffic nightmare -- though it's not too bad for the lunch hour, and we've been surprisingly trouble-free in finding parking.You need to try this place.

reviews.name: Anush J.
reviews.review: Would give a 3.5. Nothing was bad, but nothing (except for the Gobi Manchurian appetizer - which was awesome) was exceptional. Service was good. We are visiting Nashville, but have tried many an Indian restaurant, and this just does not stick out for us.

reviews.name: Habiba W.
reviews.review: I was really surprised to find a South Indian restaurant in Nashville and when I went there and tried out the food I was pleased to find out it's pretty good!  I used to go to India to visit my grandparents every summer and I'd eat South Indian food everyday so I basically go nuts in this place.  I love the lunch buffet but ordering off the menu and trying the different type of dosas really puts me in my happy place.  Lately I found the food to be a little greasier than normal but you still cannot go wrong with this place- it is so good!

reviews.name: Ben M.
reviews.review: My first four reviews have dealt primarily with my meat-eating experiences: a steakhouse, two BBQ joints, and a restaurant that serves salmon roasted in duck fat. So you could understand how I would hesitate to enter, let alone write a review for, a vegetarian establishment such as the Woodlands. Still, I was convinced by the colleague who picked this restaurant that it would be good. But it wasn't. It was great.The first task is to find the restaurant, which looks like it's downstairs from an apartment/condo complex. I didn't see any signs for the restaurant, save for the awning which isn't that visible at night. Luckily, you can find almost anything with a GPS unit.The ambiance of the restaurant left much to be desired, but it's not meant to be a fine dining experience. It's reminiscent of a dhaba, or roadside restaurant: no-frills dining area, basic tables and chairs, and food served on plates and metal trays.The night we went wasn't busy, which was great for us. Food was reasonably priced and came out quickly and in great portions. I ordered one of the three available combos, which comes with hot tea, hot soup, samosas, "dosa" (Indian crepe), and an assortment of vegetarian entrees served with two types of rice. All of it good, all of it filling, since it's mostly carbs you're consuming.They don't serve alcohol, but you're allowed to bring your own, so we had to send someone out for a six-pack.Excellent food, so-so service, hard-to-find location, but overall a good experience.

reviews.name: Marshall S.
reviews.review: I've always thought that indian food was a little to over-spiced and greasy, but not after I ate here.  It took me 2 years of living in Nashville and driving by this place to finally go in and It was awesome!   I was starving when I got there and the place was packed so I was a little worried, but they got the food out quickly and there was plenty of it for 2 people.  All the food is lightly spiced and super delicious.  I would recommend this to anyone looking for a good, moderately priced vegetarian restaurant.

reviews.name: TheTruth C.
reviews.review: OMG.... I don't even like Vegetarian food but Woodlands makes it SOOoooooo Delicious I could eat here everyday!!! Totally recommend them!!!

reviews.name: Matt J.
reviews.review: Some of the best Indian food you will come across, until you go to London or India.  The buffet is changing, so you can go often without getting bored.  It also means you can't look forward to having that thing you love.The dinner menu has a wide variety.  If you don't know what to get, get plain or masala dosa.  It is simple and universally loved.  The fact that there is Chinese food on the menu is a testament to the authenticity of this restaurant because Indians love Chinese food.

reviews.name: MJ Y.
reviews.review: 4*   "you want woodlands again???"Ok this is going to be easy :)1. Southern Indian food- with Southern hospitality :)2. Vegetarian without knowing it- So my fiance is a definite carnivore, who claims to not feel fulfilled w/o meat.. so I tricked him and didn't even tell him its vegetarian :) While enjoying/ devouring his food.... "hey is this place vegetarian???"  Well he's been back!3. Lunch Buffet- whoot! (there might be a line depending on the time... but moves quick enough) Actually I'm not a fan of buffet because it usually turns into quantity and not quality. But it's done right here. It has good variety while keeping quality~ They also switch it up. You can also order off the menu instead of buffet. Favorite? I'm sorry.... i just eat when I'm there w/o learning what I'm eating... next time! T4. BYOB- no fee5. Price- well not the cheapest... but fresh, good food- worth it!6. location/ decor- confusing at first... bc its at the bottom of a tall office (?) building. And go for the food, not decor or ambiance.

reviews.name: Brad T.
reviews.review: Oh man, talk about some good stuff! As usual, my fellow Yelpers have driven my vacation to yet another awesome restaurant. Located underneath either an apartment building or a condo complex, this somewhat hidden delight didn't even catch my eye, and I'm trained from years of Detroit dives to look very closely for small signs and faded awnings.The smell upon entering is that familiar Indian restaurant combo of fried dough, curry, and cooked vegetables. This is by no means a sign of a good or bad restaurant, but I do love that smell. We picked out a few hot items (Bombay Bhaji Dosa, Palak Paneer, the appetizer sampler) and dove right in, and sure enough it was all rock solid.A dosa is a piece of thin fried dough (similar to a crepe) that is served with dipping sauces. In my case, they were a yummy spicy tomato sauce, a chutney cream sauce, and a somewhat thin potato soup kind of thing. I'm sure there are official names for these sauces, but I don't have to know them to like them. The paneer is a traditional spinach and cottage cheese dish that is found at most Indian places, and my wife thought it was very good, but not significantly better than others she's had.In general, this was a very good Indian restaurant that probably wouldn't be the best I've ever had, but was a nice relief from the intense pork and BBQ-themed meals that have dominated our trip to Nashville. I would certainly come back next time we are in town.

reviews.name: Michael W.
reviews.review: It is so hard to find a good, hearty, affordable and healthy vegetarian meal in Nashville. Woodlands deserves all five stars for that alone. I'm pretty picky about my Indian restaurants, since I can generally get much better at an Indian friend's home. But Woodlands offers (in this ferengi's humble opinion) pretty authentic Southern Indian fare. Warming spices, earthy lentil flour, and tangy chutneys rule the day.On your first trip, the dosa is a must. Basically a crisp and slightly chewy paper-thin pancake rolled around a filling and served with dips. Try the paper masala dosa. As big as yer' head, served with comfortingly perfect potatoes masala, sambar (a savory delicious soup with potatoes and eggplant in broth), and coconut chutney, whose excellence you have to taste to believe.Feeling a bit adventurous? Give pani puri a try. Pani refers to a sweet-tangy-spicy seasoned tamarind water, which you pour into a puri, a hollow fried-crisp round bread filled with potatoes and peas. Before the whole contraption self-destructs, you pop it into your mouth whole, and whomp down on a refreshing and intensely flavorful explosion. You crunch, you slurp, you savor, and then you wipe off your chin and grab another.Curries are great too. My favorite is chana palak, chickpeas and spinach. But really everything you get is good. I can't remember the real name, but the "veggie balls" are also good, served in a creamy spicy orange sauce not unlike tikka masala.I usually warn, besmirch, doomsay, beg people to order from the menu rather than succumb to the ease of an Indian buffet, but Woodlands is the exception. Excellent buffet with a fine selection of curries, rice dishes, soups, bread, chutneys, salads and desserts. It changes daily, and if you're lucky they'll serve kheer (milky rice pudding with cardamom ) and gulab jamun (soft, ethereal donut-like pastry balls made with evaporated milk and served in a way-too-sweet-in-a-good-way-man-i-can't-stop-eating-this syrup)If you know what's good for you, you'll try this place.

reviews.name: Jason S.
reviews.review: Delicious, healthful, and very reasonably priced vegetarian food.  Nashville is a tough town for vegetarian food and this is as good as it gets (with the possible exception of the Wild Cow...)

reviews.name: Kelan T.
reviews.review: This indian buffet has remarkable range and the food quality stands up to the dishes I've eaten in southern India.  As I enjoyed plate after plate of perfectly seasoned delicious vegetarian cuisine they even dropped off a fresh dosa to complement the feast.  Completely unexpected in the state of Tennessee...I've never had anything in SF, LA or NY that approaches this value.

reviews.name: Peter K.
reviews.review: I feel as though I need to update my review and really call out people that haven't the faintest of a clue when it comes to real Indian food.  Woodlands is the most authentic Indian joint in town, period.  You can't find dosa's, special thali's, or a variety of different curries anywhere else in the Nashville area.  Paul, maybe you failed to notice your surroundings, but the majority of the customers at Woodlands are Indian.  They probably just like the idea of Indian food, but can't handle the spices.  lolol

reviews.name: Abi T.
reviews.review: I was wilting with hunger when I got to Woodlands, so everything on the menu looked amazing. I was especially impressed with the wide selection of Indian dishes, many of which I had never seen before. After a samosa appetizer, my hunger-induced panic was relieved a bit and I dug into a Vegetable Utahappa, an "Indian style pancake made of rice n lentil with various toppings." The vegetable version has tomatoes, peas and onions cooked right in and is served with a couple of different chutneys. I really loved it, but since it was my first time to try it, I supposed I can't really compare it to other restaurant's Utahppa. The service was a bit awkward, with a whole team of waiters working our table, but not communicating very well with each other. We were asked to place an order several times, but at least we weren't abandoned!I'll definitely go again, especially to try the Dosa, another Indian specialty I've missed out on in life so far: "Thin Rice Crepes served with sambar & chutney (coconut sauce)." I also suggest this spot when I'm dining with Vegetarians, since it's always nice for them to be able to order anything off the menu. And with so many dishes they've never seen before, Omnivore's won't even notice there isn't any meat.

reviews.name: Truth S.
reviews.review: We love this place always, but it is banging tonight! Absolutely sublime from beginning to end. We did take-out this time, gobi manchurian dry, papad, fried rice, masala dosa, and palak paneer, also extra cilantro mint chutney cause that stuff is awesome. If you are looking for the best Indian food in Nashville-whether you are vegetarian or not- Woodlands is your place.

reviews.name: Andi D.
reviews.review: Woodlands is probably one of my favorite restaurants in Nashville.  I have never once had a bad dish or bad experience here. Impeccable service, amazing food.I'm glad they do the buffet on the weekends, because it's a bit far from my office to make the trip for lunch during the week.

reviews.name: Kate O.
reviews.review: Woodlands is one of only two fully vegetarian restaurants in Nashville (the other being Grins at Vanderbilt), at least as I write this, so you would think that, as a committed vegan, I'd be there a lot. But from a vegan perspective, Woodlands isn't actually any easier than any other Indian restaurant: you still have to ask which items use ghee (clarified butter) in preparation, and you have to hope that the waiter knows or is willing to ask the kitchen staff. That said, the food is tasty, and some of the less-common menu items are worth exploring. The staff is friendly and accommodating, and the portions are generous enough for leftovers.

reviews.name: Jennifer M.
reviews.review: I headed to Woodlands earlier this week for a group outing. The Indian, vegatarian, no alcohol setting isn't exactly the ideal hot spot for this carnivorous drinker who doesn't like Indian food. Nonetheless, I enjoyed the experience! I tried the appetizer sampler which seemed to me to just be various breaded,deep-fried vegetables, and weren't particularly exciting, but did come with some interesting sauces, one which was bright green and great for people like me who enjoy some spicy flair. I was very hungry and didn't want to be stuck with a dinner I didn't like, so I wussed out and ordered the vegetarian noodles (spicy, of course). The noodles were great, though probably more Chinesey than Indian. In short, I really enjoyed my visit against all odds. Thus, if you like vegatarian Indian food (hold the glass of wine), I bet you'll love Woodlands!

reviews.name: David A.
reviews.review: Good food and atmosphere at this quaint Indian Restaurant.  The food is well seasoned and prepared and the wait staff is very helpful. The table seating is fairly close so be prepared for a little noise. On the whole a good experience for the senses.

reviews.name: Art Q.
reviews.review: Being vegetarian-curious, i'm always on the lookout for a new place to try meatless dining. Enter Woodlands. I love Indian food, and most restaurants do a decent job of it. Woodlands is, regardless of meat disposition, a cut above the rest (except maybe Shalimar in Green Hills, whose tandoori chicken is unbeatable). The buffet is a great option for lunch, but check out the dinner plate combos (I think they're in the back of the menu) other times. It's a good way to get acclimated to the food Woodlands serves. Don't forget your dosa, and don't be afraid to try the bread options other than naan. There's some good stuff there.

reviews.name: Kiran G.
reviews.review: If ur bill is less than 10$ make sure u have cash. If not, it is going to be a bad experience here.

reviews.name: Dawn D.
reviews.review: You pay a bit under $10 for the lunch buffet, but they also bring you free crepes-like food with something inside :) That's how far my Indian food knowledge goes. But the taste of most of their food is great, and flavors are rich. Definitely worth checking out.

reviews.name: Erin J.
reviews.review: I've eaten here many times, and it's been great each visit.  Some of my favorites are....the daily soup (can't remember the name, but really spicy), cauliflower soup, vegetable korma, chana palak.  And I love the chutneys....the tamarind is my absolute favorite!  The fried items are really good if you can get them fresh (like the fried eggplant pieces).  The salad (lettuce, tomatoes, carrots, cucumber) & raita are great for cooling off after a big bite of something really spicy.  Beware the preserved lemon!  I learned the hard way the first time I ever tried some of that.....I chomped down on a whole piece of it...oooh, bad idea.  Just stick with the saucy part - it's really good!

reviews.name: Carlos V.
reviews.review: A great selection of gluten-fee dishes. The food is excellent!

reviews.name: Rahul I.
reviews.review: This is a good South Indian restaurant in Nashville.  I am glad I found it.  Not too many South Indian restaurants in Nashville these days.  This a place that I hope stays in business.  You can not go wrong with their dosais, or with the bhel puri, or pani puri.

reviews.name: Emma L.
reviews.review: Don't even talk about it.This is my favorite restaurant. Seriously. Even non-vegetarians will go away feeling so satisfied, and even someone with weak taste buds like me can tolerate the spice.Must-tries include the vegetable samosas (2 large ones per order), aloo mutter (yummy, basic curry), batura (huge puffy) or poori (medium wheat puffy) bread, and the Indian coffee. Also, their ice cream is lovely and fragrant.Go with friends and split many dishes and be very, very happy.Note: No alcohol sold, but you can bring it

reviews.name: Carolyn M.
reviews.review: I finally made it to Woodlands Indian Vegetarian today for lunch.  I arrived early right when the buffet food was getting out so everything was hot and fresh.I really enjoyed the lentil and potato dish.  The only thing the lunch buffet was missing was some naan.  Not that I was scooping the scene, but Woodlands Indian Vegetarian Cuisine is THE place for  spotting men.  I didn't notice how hot they were, because like I said, I wasn't looking, but there was a 20 to 2 male-female ratio upon final count.You know, go, eat some yummy veggie food, and maybe get a hot date over the buffet bar.  Something like, "that dahl is really yummy, you should try it!  oh and by the way, is anyone sitting next to you?"  HAPPY VEGAN DINING!

reviews.name: Trace S.
reviews.review: I became addicted to Woodlands lunch buffet after learning of this establishment on Yelp.  One morning around 11:30am I happened upon some reviews of this place and the more I read, the hungrier I became. Next thing I know, I'm rocketing along on I-440 imagining how great it's gonna be!I LOVED IT! I was a little put off after reading it is a vegetarian place, but PLEASE UNDERSTAND, I am a big-time meateater and I did not miss meat being in these dishes at all!  Think about it, there's really nothing unique that chicken brings to an Indian dish at all. It's the spices and sauces that make the flavors so addictive. Tell your meat-eating friends to be adventurous and give it a try. They won't miss the meat at all. It's not the kind of place that's trying to substitute a soy or rice product into dishes in the shape of a chicken breast. LOLSince my first visit, I've been back to Woodlands on average 2x/week. I have enjoyed the best variety of dishes on their buffet of any Indian place I've ever dined. Can't say enough good things about it!

reviews.name: Michaela M.
reviews.review: The best Indian food in town! I love their lunch buffet. The atmosphere is not the greatest, and I've encountered friendlier staff, but the food totally makes up for it all. Well, and it's not exactly that the staff is unfriendly, just not very personable, and they have some odd rules about buffet-take-out. Very set in their ways about that...This is my favorite Indian restaurant in Nashville. Hands down.

reviews.name: JJ S.
reviews.review: Great find on a whim! Though it was a little hard to locate (for those who are looking it's attached to the continental hotel). The lunch buffet offers great traditional Indian food (less cream more spice!) with a good selection of chutneys for your taste bud's delight. Although the cuisine is vegetarian only, omnivores alike will find something to satisfy their hunger. And if you haven't tried Indian food yet, this is a great option for you. Overall, good food for a good price.

reviews.name: moore t.
reviews.review: Fabulous, fabulous, and xtra fabulous!I believe the Dolce is their specialty - you can't go wrong with ordering one of these.  Hearty and filling,the portions are huge and the atmosphere is relaxing.also have a lunch buffet, but, to be honest, to order off the menu is far more satisfying.

reviews.name: Heather R.
reviews.review: I had always wanted to try Indian food, so when I found Woodlands googling along one day, my husband and I ran at the chance to try it. I'm still amazed at just how spicy the food can be, but really, what was I expecting? That's like assuming ice cream isn't cold. It was so tasty, and they had these desert dumpling type things that reminded me of (or something along the line) of banana pudding. I sooo recommend those. The waiters were unobtrusive and were there to fill our water and walk on to their next table. It's served buffet style, which is fine with me, because these poor guys probably couldn't understand my butchered southern pronunciation of the meals. The last thing I have to add is be aware that it's kind of hidden. It looks like the entrance to a motel, and for the first few months we were living here, I thought it was one.

reviews.name: Misty S.
reviews.review: This is my favorite restaurant in Nashville. Such delicious food and they will make it as mild or as spicy as you like. BYOB and no corking fee. My husband and I can eat well for $15. I want Woodlands to cater every party I throw. AMAZING.

reviews.name: Stephanie R.
reviews.review: Nashville is so lacking in ethnic restaurants. Woodlands is one of the few decent ones.  Its the best Indian in town, for sure, but that isn't really saying much.I always have a good meal here, the food is always flavorful and what you expect. Meat eaters should consider that Woodlands is vegetarian only before visiting, but I don't find that as problematic as some might.

reviews.name: Kyla A.
reviews.review: When I discovered that there was an Indian restaurant (or any restaurant for that matter) where a vegetarian like myself could just point to anything on the menu and be OK I was pumped.  I set out the next night with my roommate to check it out.  The selection is stupendous and there are lots of dishes on the menu I haven't seen at the other Indian restaurants in town, even in a meaty version.  The food is delicious and the prices are just as easy to stomach.  I love that each time I can get something totally different.  That kind of selection in one restaurant is a rare treat for me.  My roommate who isn't a vegetarian enjoyed our first meal just as much as I did.As Helena pointed out, the interior of the place isn't all that exciting so I usually get take out instead.

reviews.name: Virginia G.
reviews.review: We had a great dinner here with some friends on a Thursday night, and it was not at all crowded.  My friends have eaten there many times, even though neither they nor my husband are vegetarians.  Everything we ordered was great - we had samosa appetizers and then split three entrees and two orders of naan among us.  We were all stuffed, and there was still a little leftover.  I don't remember exactly what we tried, but there was nothing that I wouldn't recommend again!

reviews.name: Declan G.
reviews.review: So far, Woodlands is my favorite Indian restaurant in Nashville.  I'm used to only having two or three vegetarian options to choose from when I eat out, so Woodlands was a welcome change.  The service is good, and the two dishes and the naan we ordered were all so tasty that I wished they didnt' fill me up so quickly.  Woodlands' prices are also lower than the average Indian restaurant, which is a plus, especially since you're still getting a high quality meal.  I'd recommend trying to gulab jamman for desert - warm, doughy fried cheese balls soaked in sweet rose water, mmmmm.  Other reviewers have criticized Woodlands' decor, but I think it has an appealingly quirky and interesting look, compared to the more proper Indian restaurants I've visited.  The one drawback to Woodlands is that if your date is a steadfast omnivore, you'll have to go elsewhere.

reviews.name: Nancy V.
reviews.review: Warning: if you eat here for a business lunch - you will find the flavor very distracting. I'm not sure why it took me so long to eat here but I will be back often. The lunch buffet was fantastic.

reviews.name: Jagannathan S.
reviews.review: We visit Nashville frequently and invariably woodlands is on our list of places to visit! Food is very good. As part of buffet, you get masala dosai and a wide variety of vegetarian dishes. For dessert, thy have 3-4 Choices. Buffet prices Are very reasonable, 9.99 per person. If I have a complaint, it is locating a parking spot. There is more parking in the back of what seems like an apartment complex. Service is very good. I wish they opened a branch in Atlanta!

reviews.name: Charles A.
reviews.review: Best vegetarian offering in Nashville. I have now gone there for dinner and their lunch buffet.  I have been satisfied with everything that I have had and love the variety.  I went with friends who are from India and they explained that most of the food from Woodlands is Southern Indian Cuisine.  There is a difference between Southern and Northern Indian cuisine, which is seems like southern cuisine is lighter and not as fried and heavy with sauces.  The Dosa and Utapa is excellent.  When you go for the buffet, they have a mix of Southern and Northern cuisine and they bring Dosa to your table.  YUM!The soups are excellent, especially Sambar, and are good with Idley (a small rice cake/roll).  If you go, definitely go for the lunch buffet and try everything, you will be amazed how full and satisfied you can get on food without meat.

reviews.name: Bill S.
reviews.review: The dinner specials are great.  They have a variety of small samples.  I had the WOODLAND SPECIAL THALI...It was huge.  My girlfriend and I both got Dinner specials and were eating leftovers for 2 days.  The hot tea and the iced tea were quality..a must try.  I have to agree with Heather's review, that "desert dumpling type thing" was awesome.  It's covered in honey...sooooo good.

reviews.name: Helena S.
reviews.review: The food ...good stuff! Delightful, great portions, leftovers for sure. I didn't care for the actual ambiance though, I felt like a time traveled back to the 80's in India.

reviews.name: Katherine M.
reviews.review: Woodlands is a fabulous Indian restaurant. Even though it is a vegetarian restaurant, there's plenty to eat and you won't leave hungry. Trust. I love Indian food and this is at the top of my list.Try starting with a soup, such as Rasam which is spicy/sour . Or Bhel Puri is an excellent appetizer. The Mysore Masala Dosai is my favorite entree. It all depends on what type of Indian food you like, but they have it all! Woodland's Special Dosai is a local favorite. Be adventurous. Of course their Indian bread and curried dishes are wonderful. They have a lunch buffet for those wanting to sample a little bit of everything.Give it a try. You'll most likely run into me there!

reviews.name: Betty H.
reviews.review: Excellent service, delicious vegetarian dishes, and very reasonable prices.  We eat here at least once a week and are never disappointed.  It is vegetarian and they do not serve alcohol, but many people bring in their own beer or wine.

reviews.name: Shaun C.
reviews.review: Woodlands is EXCELLET! From the Sunday buffet to the many selections on the menu.  I have been there at least 15 times in the past 3 months and I'm also ready to go again.  Warning for the meat eaters (like me): This is a vegan restaurant with a lot of curry selections.  This place was a great new place for me and made me open my eyes to vegan cuisine.  :)  -Shaun

reviews.name: Dan B.
reviews.review: You can get some pretty interesting Indian dishes here.  They specialize in a kind of "Indian crepe."  I forgot what it was called.  I tried some, though,and it was very good.  They have alot of weird spices/sauces that they give you on the side.  Some are great, some are just okay.  I had the chick pea dish.  It was great.

reviews.name: Shawn B.
reviews.review: I went here on a trip based on reviews on Yelp. My friend and I both enjoyed the meal greatly. The food was tasty and served quickly. The price was reasonable too. We both recommended Woodlands to folks looking for Indian or vegetarian food in Nashville.

reviews.name: Joshua P.
reviews.review: An incredible restaurant for both vegetarians and non. Good buffet selection, good service (they always keep my drink filled), and a relatively large menu.By far my favorite Indian restaurant in Nashville.

reviews.name: J R.
reviews.review: I'm not even a vegetarian and I love this place! I've been for their lunch buffet a couple times. They have a great variety of things to try that you don't find at the other Indian restaurants.I especially love their lemon pickles. So sour and so tasty!

reviews.name: James E.
reviews.review: Pretty Tasty, nothing amazing.  I gave it 3 stars because I eat meat lol.  If I was a  vegetarian I would give it 4.Get crazy when ordering.

reviews.name: Larry R.
reviews.review: My wife and I are foodies and love Indian food.  We have eaten in Indian restaurants across the country.  This place is outstanding.  We went to the buffet two times when we were in Nashville.  We love restaurants and only once in ten times in a city will we go back to the same place which shows you  how special this place is.  We did the lunch buffet twice and the flavors were so deep, full and complicated in every dish.  Choices were different both times and amazing.  Not the stuff you usually see in these buffets.  There are plenty of different things to choose and the service is great.   The customers were mostly Indians and there are other places they could go so that tells you something.  Try this place!!

reviews.name: Matthew S.
reviews.review: Solid Indian fare. While I am not a vegetarian, I do love Woodlands for its wide variety of authentic offerings. Not the best Indian food ever,  but the best near Nashville for sure. I have only been a few times and what I can say is that the food is well prepared, spiced nicely, and is served in very nice portion sizes. The restaurant was clean and I found no problems with the service. I usually choose a couple standard dishes to compare different Indian restaurants. I started with the Channa Masala. While it was a little al dente for my personal tastes, it was very good and I would order it again. There was enough sauce to scrape some up with my naan, but not so much that I had to go searching for the chickpeas. They serve your menu choice and the rice on separate dishes, allowing you to mix (or not) on your plate as you prefer. Overall, a solid dish, in keeping with a very positive experience. Despite being completely vegetarian, they offer a very extensive menu. There are even a few things on there that I haven't tried yet (and I used to eat A LOT of Indian food). Vegetarian or not, if you want Indian food in the Nashville area, you would be wise to check out the amazing selection at Woodlands.Note: It is a little hard to see if you have not been there before. It is across the street from the gas station right after you get off of the highway. From the road I couldn't see the name of the restaurant behind the trees until after I passed it.

reviews.name: Priya A.
reviews.review: I never expected Tennessee to have such good Indian food!!!! Their Gobi Manchurian is amazing..and then I love their bhel puri and chaats..  I even tried their buffet one day and it was great..  I would def recommend this place for anyone looking for good Indian food. They have some other restaurant in the downtown called Tamarind which I want to try next.. :)

reviews.name: Erin D.
reviews.review: The only Indian food I had ever eaten prior to Woodlands was homemade by my friend's Indian mother. My first trip to Woodlands was with said friend whose mother absolutely loved it. I'm a huge fan of the fact that it's vegetarian. I love their Masala Dosa, and Aloo Gobi and Kadai Bendi Masala curries. Oh and their Naan is great! My favorite is to go as a group and order a series of different curries and everyone picks at them family style. That's what it's all about! The service is great and ordering by the number next to the item isn't discouraged. I never knew it was here because it's tucked away in what appears to be an apartment building, but the food is fantastic. Parking isn't usually a problem but I can see during a peak time that it could be.

reviews.name: Michael N.
reviews.review: Ate here on Tuesday night. Nice people. Food very tasty. I'm not a veg, but enjoy good food of any kind. My vegan dining partner had a lot to choose from. Best dish was the tomato soup, but everything was great. Prices reasonable as well. I'd definitely go back if in the area.

reviews.name: kimbe m.
reviews.review: I went to Woodlands yesterday, based on the good reviews here. Maybe I caught the swing shift; it was only 4 pm. The raitha was so watered down that it didn't even cling to my chapati when I dipped it. The mint sauce was likewise watery and tasteless. The waiter couldn't explain any of the dishes, except to nod his head and say "Yes, hot" when I asked if something could be made extra-spicy. The food was forgettable at best, and thesoup advertised as traditional spicy Indian tomato soup tasted exactly like Campbell's tomato soup from a can, with some black pepper added. I live just outside Nashville and am always in search of great food here. Perhaps the lunch buffet is better, but for "real" Indian food locally, Shalimar is still, sadly, the only game in town.

reviews.name: kristen p.
reviews.review: I keep meaning to review this place but the fact that i know very little about indian food has been intimidating me. That aside I have very much enjoyed my experiences here. Even when they are not having a buffet they still have some great platters for sampling. I have been a vegetarian for ten years so going into a restaurant where I can order absolutely anything off the menu is somewhat of a novelty.

reviews.name: Douglas B.
reviews.review: A fabulous Indian restaurant.  The lunch buffet is matchless and a wonderful way to sample Indian delicacies.  The place gets very busy but they keep up with the pace; fresh food is constantly appearing on the buffet table. They also operate Tamarind restaurant,  which serves non-vegetarian cuisine.

reviews.name: John W.
reviews.review: the only truely vegetarian joint in the 'ville that is open year-round. came here for the lunch buffett and filled up on portions of yummy dishes like masla dosa, palak paneer, and idli. i also recommend the spiced coffee or tea.

reviews.name: Tart L.
reviews.review: One of only two or three totally vegetarian restaurants in Nashville, Woodlands is a treat for vegetarians in particular and healthy eaters in general. You can enjoy the lunch buffet or order from the menu for lunch and dinner. Many of the classic Indian dishes are offered, and the waiters will be happy to describe the selections for those new to healthy Indian cooking. Be adverturesome, and try a bit of some of the buffet items that are new to you. For those new to Indian veggie cooking, I recommend the lunch buffet your first time.

reviews.name: bloopie s.
reviews.review: Um, yes. Even if the only thing Woodland's had was a GIANT vat of sambar with idlis piled up high, they would still get my 5 stars. Hell, they'd get all my stars. This is what tasty vegetarian tastes like. And their gulab jaman are the most perfect little fried balls in syrup EVER!

reviews.name: Emily Y.
reviews.review: I always order the #37 special Woodlands dosa.  Another favorite is the vegetarian cutlet.  But, don't forget to check out the bread selection on the last page--I can't remember the name of it, but get the one stuffed with potatoes and spices.  Dinner is best, I don't love the lunch buffet.  Great for a cold winter evening too!

reviews.name: Liliana G.
reviews.review: went for the lunch buffet.  the food was good but the buffet was very small.  i am used to seeing twice the number of dishes.  they did give us some free dosas though so that lessened the sting.  chutney's and naan were delish! can't remember what htey were called but the lentil pancake thingys were my fave!!  they reminded me of the southern bbq standard- corncakes- with their slightly sour flavor.

reviews.name: Melody H.
reviews.review: I really love Woodland's. It is easily one of my favorite places to eat. Indian is by far my very favorite food, and this is my favorite Indian restaurant in Nashville. Also, I'm a vegetarian, and it's not always easy to find a good variety for vegetarians, but that is not the case here. I have always found the staff to be very friendly, I've been there so much that they remember me now every time I go in. Price is good, and nothing beats their lunch buffet!! Some of my personal favorites are: for appetizers- vegetable samosa, homemade spring rolls, and the assorted appetizer. Uthappam- tomato and peas. Curries- Palak Paneer, Baigan Barta, and Aloo Palak. Desserts- Gulab Jamun, Carrot Halwa, Rassmalai, and I almost NEVER eat ice cream, but I highly recommend the Mango ice cream. It tastes like a mango!  They don't serve alcohol, but you can bring your own wine (beer & liquor, I'm not sure) and either the corking fee is cheap, or non-existent.

reviews.name: Mackenzie R.
reviews.review: Great experience. Had some great local brews and a fantastic burger! Unique vibe, good music, definitely different from most bars on Broadway. The best places are normally hidden away holes in the wall, and this place attests to that! Will definitely be returning.

reviews.name: Stray W.
reviews.review: I'm not too sure why they've gotten the "best burger in Nashville" award because really, their burgers were at best, mediocre. I definitely don't think their prices are great, over $14 for a burger (extra cost for bacon and cheese!) and even a charge for fries! Not just that, I barely even got a handful of fries (9 to be exact) and they just weren't that good. The wait for my ridiculous, over 45 minutes and there is was hardly anyone in here. It's constantly loud and I feel like everyone is yelling at one another. Also, it was rather cold in there and no one seemed to want to do anything.  Overall, I'm not overly satisfied with this place. Not worth it.

reviews.name: Chelsea P.
reviews.review: Not impressed. Bartender wasn't friendly and when we asked for water, we were given bottles. Didn't think we'd be charged - just that that's what they do. Nope, $2 each. Are you kidding? Menu is only a chalk board - so if one of the pillars or a person is blocking it, good luck...Go elsewhere - plenty of better spots on the strip.

reviews.name: Leighton B.
reviews.review: To put it as nicely as I can, everything about this meal and experience was sub par. I once stopped here for a drink on the Pedal Tavern and remember seeing a sign that boasted "best burger in Nashville!" After ordering the cheeseburger, I realized that statement was about as true as the stuff you read on Wikipedia. It was a bland burger, nothing more and nothing less. The fries were good, though. The service, to also put it nicely, was pretty bad. When my brother and I walked in, we didn't know if we were supposed to seat ourselves or order at the bar. So, for about 5 minutes we waited at the bar, where there were only 3 or 4 other customers, and finally the bartender came over to take our order. My brother and I, we're pretty friendly, non-pushy people. But the bartender seemed put out by every request we made. I don't think she cracked a smile the entire time we were there.One last complaint and I swear I'll be done...I asked for a cup of water and then the bartender brought me a bottled water and charged me $2. I asked her if I could get a cup of tap water but she said they only had bottled water. Since when do restaurants literally FORCE you to pay for water?To sum it up, save your money and appetite for somewhere with better service and better food.

reviews.name: Tommy C.
reviews.review: I rarely write reviews when traveling but this food is absolutely terrible. There's a nice man wrangling people in with the audacious claim "best food in Nashville"( and that's why I went in, so good for him I guess) , but that is honestly the most outlandishly inaccurate statement that could possibly be made. Stay away. Beer served in 12 Oz plastic cup too...

reviews.name: Morgan M.
reviews.review: Don't waste your time coming here. The bartender was pleasant, but the owner/manager was a jerk and completely ruined the experience.

reviews.name: Matt C.
reviews.review: I've never had the opportunity to use the disclaimer that the only reason I gave it one star was because a no-star option was not available...until now. From the beginning the service was absolutely terrible.  When we asked for menus. The server's response was, "It's posted (inside on a chalkboard...I suggest you take a picture.."  Some food came earlier than the rest...not everyone got silverware...we were told it was in the dishwasher...bad, bad, bad...keep walking past this joint

reviews.name: Audrey S.
reviews.review: Bad customer service will always ruin a restaurant experience. My sister and I stopped in to The Underground for a morning snack during the CMA Fest going on in downtown Nashville. We wanted a mimosa or two and a bite to eat before the next concerts started, so at first we ordered waters, the unlimited mimosas for $20 per person, and an egg sandwich to split.
